reviews.text:
A very unique place. It’s just a little plate located in a quiet neighborhood but it holds so much history and meaning.

Standing there at 10pm at night by myself. It felt a little bit eerie thinking about how the bomb exploded right above this location decades ago.

This place is a reminder that with the Japanese resilience and capabilities, cities could be rebuilt and flourish in no time at all.

This place is a must-visit for me every time I go to Peace Park. While many people visit the Peace Park, Atomic Bomb Dome, and museum, this location holds significant importance as it marks the hypocenter where the atomic bomb first exploded. There's only one label placed in front of the hospital to provide information and write the history of the place. I highly recommend visiting for those who want to study the detailed history of Hiroshima.
Worth a visit. One of the most historic places in Asia. Seeing the devastation an atomic bomb did hopefully will deter future uses by superpowers.
It is a simple marking of the ground zero of the bomb. But it is easy to just walk past it without noticing
The estimated ground point where the bomb exploded (it did it on the air). Its a small memorial right there on the street.

data.name: Nakajima district Atomic bomb damage explanation board

reviews.text: The plaques around this place are really well crafted and offer a lot of details about the A-bomb

Atomic bomb damage explanation board
No.29: Nakajima district

Incredible A-bombed survivor camphor tree at the edge of the Hiroshima castle 🏯 moat next to the playground with views of the castle 🏯
The way this tree grew back toward the direction of the nuclear blast of 1945 is fascinating
Almost no one knows it, but it is one of the 5 trees that survived the nuclear bomb. It is an indescribable feeling to be standing in front of one of these.
Tree that survived the atomic bomb
Living strong even after being exposed to the atomic bomb
Interessante! História pura.
A small shopping area and amusement park.. the aquarium made me sad because of how small the tanks are. I wouldn’t recommend that portion.
A tiny amusement park! Great for kids and families!! If you want to get out and do something, this is the perfect spot for you!
A tiny amusement park. Little kids can enjoy it.

A small entertainment space within the marina, nice for young kids.
No entrance fee but pay for each attractions.

💜💜💜
if you'd like to refresh your self go here sit down its cool and nice place and I love it here.

We LOVED this park! We don’t speak Japanese hardly at all and we’re worried there would be a language barrier but everything was great. The best part is that it is self guided so we took our time and had fun! After learning how to work the equipment we did all four courses. Each different and fun. The Tarzan swing and the zip lines where favorites of ours.

The only thing preventing me from a 5 star review is the journey there. On the way there we took hyw 289 which led onto 42. Would not recommend unless your on a motor bike. On the way back we took 488 that led onto 186 which was better but very windy. The roads are small. Bumpy. And sharp unsafe drop offs 50% of the way there. It took us 20 extra minutes because the roads were wet and very narrow we felt unsafe a lot of the time. We never met another car but we literally don’t know what we would have done if we did. I’m sure there are better roads that we did not take. But I would not recommend the “quickest and free” option route google maps will take you from Iwakuni.
Had a great time!!  Stumbled upon it and had to do.  Some of the obstacles were very challenging but managed to pass them all.  Will go back!

Life Changing, Family Bonding, Treetop Adventure
I think it helps if you are a little afraid of heights, which I am, because by the time you have been three times around the forest on each of the tree top courses, either you will be reduced to a quivvering wreck or your fear of heights will be cured. The circuits use a think stainless steel rope strung from tree to tree upon which guests are attached by a rope to a harness which they climb into. There is also a secondary line attacked to carabineer clip which is largely  unnecessary but increases the fear. There are several zip lines one of which is 150m long for the finale. I anticipated that, in typical Japanese fashion, there would be loads of staff pandering to the fears of the guests but such is the thickness of the steel rope to which guests are threaded, once you are up in the trees you are on your own. I did not fall once, which in retrospect I think was a mistake. I should have deliberately jumped off one of the tree to tree tightropes so as to test the steel roped harness and convince myself of its safety.

The only thing that I thought might be dangerous is that the extra carabineer line that customers affix themselves might, in the case of young and inept person, get caught around their head causing them to be hung if they were to fall off. There is just one place where the harness is detached from the steel rope, at the Tarzan swing, at which point it is important not to panic. The nearby  park restaurant is also recommended for good food and lots of souvenirs.

I only wish that there were more views, and one of these parks on a mountain looking down on Yamaguchi City. The only view at this park is down.

It is good way to bond with your teenage son, who in our case, is less fearful than his father.  You can get a group photo at the beginning and the end by which time you may have turned into a different person.

Great place for a family outing.

Plenty of parking rot. You can have lunch at Moninoki.
This was a lot of fun! Very challenging, mentally and physically! The staff was great!

Fun for the entire family!! I wouldn't be honest if I didn't say we were scared ro do the jump down. Though the ropes catch you, it's still a little daunting to put your trust in it. Ages 6 and up can do the rock climbing. 5 amd below have a little trampoline and small obstacle corse.
My family loves Chu Pea Park. We come here a few times a year to do wall climbing. In the summer we go to the water park. The staff is very friendly ans some of them speak English.

Great place to enjoy the hot summer with the whole family, kids under 3y/o are free of charge. Make sure to bring cash for food*, for renting a space to hang out, and for parking which is only ¥1000 for the whole day. *If you plan on buying food in there I recommend to buy food before 3pm, most shops stop selling food at that time. You can also bring your own food. Don't forgot to bring your little ones' pool floatings.
Great experience for our 3 climbers! Friendly staff and reasonable prices. Excellent rest area upstairs for the parents.
Well, there is an obstacle course, trampolines, rock climbing. For Rock climbing you have to wear a special harness and a helmet.

It took 30 minutes by bus from Fukuyama station. It is a bit difficult to go there during normal day. But during holiday, they have direct bus. It is small compare to universal studios or desney resort. I love the dinosaur park. It look like real dinosaur. The water park open during summer only.
Beautiful place for family bonding.. it's more than just a theme park..

If going during the off season, you can just drive right there and enter.   During the weekday of the off season, rides were open and the staff was super friendly.   Many shops and restaurant spots were closed.   The Orange pool area looked to be fun.   It will open in a week or two.
Amusement park and swimming 🏊‍♀️ pool. Place to enjoy summer and like wise nice to visit and  see their illumination at winter ❄️

It's a really small amusement park but really fun for the kids! Also my husband and I really enjoyed it! We would definitely go back if it was closer to our house. The ladies that work at the pasta and pizza shop are not very nice or friendly. It's quite small so the hours that it's open are perfect to spend a fun day!

data.formatted_address: Japan, 〒731-4301 Hiroshima, Aki District, Saka, 亀石山２１１２０ 字亀石山1120-10 広島ベイサイドフォート2F
data.name: Kid's US.LAND Hiroshima Bayside Fort shop

reviews.text: A fantastic place to spend an afternoon with the kids. There are so many things to do, and once you pay for admission everything inside is free. Even parents can find something entertaining. There are games, athletic activities, karaoke, tables to rest at, manga, and more. I highly recommend it.
My kids love this place 😅i recommend,we live far but because of ny kids i dont mind driving 2 hrs by expresway.good place for kids
The playground it’s enormous and fantastic, my kids enjoyed

I went on a weekday when Asoview was offering 30% off. It's on the 2nd floor of the home center. There was plenty of space with only one or two groups per playground. There are plenty of seats, so you can relax. There is also a good selection of manga, and you are free to bring your own lunch, so it might be a good idea to bring your own lunch. Once it gets a certain size, adults can also enjoy it as a children's version of Round One. There was also karaoke, table tennis, souvenir photos, games (such as Taiko no Tatsujin), massage chairs, and other relaxing spaces.

I had a chance to visit with my three little kids.
It was quite crowded as it was a holiday and unfortunately the weather was chilly.

There was a relatively large amount of play equipment, so I was spoiled for choice.

It said there was a space to eat, so I went to a convenience store to get one, but since everyone was playing with their tables held down, it was hard to find a space.It's convenient, but it can be a problem when it's crowded...⤵️

It seemed like there was almost no age limit for the play equipment, but it was impossible for two people to watch 6, 4, and 2 year olds at the same time...(lol)
It's so spacious that it's easy to run and disappear and lose sight of it...⤵️

Each corner was set aside for babies, but elementary school students were almost never accompanied by children, so they often had to run into the kids running around or monopolize the play equipment. I felt like it would be good to be careful at times.
Baby might be a little chilly on the weekend since it's a public holiday...

Children who come in groups will probably have fun, but if the group monopolizes the play equipment, small children on their own may find it difficult to get in, or they may not be able to use some of the equipment, so I think they might be a little reluctant to go on weekends or holidays.

There are some game consoles where if you have two, you can't use one, so you might have to wait a little while it's crowded.
It's possible on weekdays, but I'd like it to be fully operational during busy times.

Purchase a one-day ticket at a convenience store for 5,400 yen for three children and two adults.

Hmm...hmm...I guess it's a little weird~😣

All in all, the three kids said it was fun🎵😂
If I go, I'd probably go on a weekday.

By the way, do I need a massage device?
I think people will realize that it's okay to leave it alone...
Is it possible to separate the dining table so that people can leave their seats after eating?

I visited Hiroshima Gate Park at the end of the day and took the opportunity to eat at the various food stalls. It's important to be careful, as many of the stalls serve extremely spicy dishes and even compete with each other to see who can make the spiciest food. Despite the heat, it was a fun and delicious way to end the day, experiencing the local flavors and vibrant atmosphere.

Hiroshima GatePark is a public park that was rebuilt on the former Hiroshima Municipal Stadium. It has many shops and restaurants, as well as a large covered area for people to relax. The park also hosts short-term events, so there is occasionally something new to see.

we ate at eggs and things and the food was okay. we had it in Hawaii and it was way better. the potatoes were raw and the pork nachos used cheap tortilla chips and was tasted like Velveeta cheese as topping. I would avoid ordering that.
Very nice, spacious and modern park with some restaurants in the area.
A nice place to relax and to grab a bite to eat. Here you're in between the peace memorial park, the A bomb dome, and the peace pagoda.

data.formatted_address: １丁目-1-10 Nakajimachō, Naka Ward, Hiroshima, 730-0811, Japan
data.name: Peace Memorial Park - Hiroshima

reviews.text:
Peace Memorial Park in Hiroshima is a poignant testament to the resilience of the human spirit in the face of devastating tragedy. Established to commemorate the victims of the atomic bombing in 1945, the park serves as a serene oasis amidst the bustling city.

The park's design seamlessly blends natural elements with poignant memorials, creating a contemplative atmosphere. The Peace Memorial Museum within the park provides a comprehensive historical narrative, offering visitors a deep understanding of the impact of the atomic bomb. The A-Bomb Dome, a UNESCO World Heritage Site, stands as a haunting reminder of the destructive power unleashed on that fateful day.

Visitors often describe the experience as emotionally powerful, with the Children's Peace Monument and the Memorial Cenotaph evoking profound reflections on the consequences of war. The park's commitment to promoting peace and nuclear disarmament is evident through various events and activities held throughout the year.

While the park is a somber reminder of the past, it also inspires hope for a future free from nuclear threats. A visit to Peace Memorial Park is not just a historical exploration but a deeply moving and educational journey that encourages contemplation on the importance of peace and unity.

The park is very beautiful and marks an important historical site. Unfortunately, it is the location of choice for many, many schoolchildren. We went on a seemingly popular day for field trips, and the museum was so crowded with kids it was impossible to even read the plaques, never mind the fact that it was hot and everyone was moving at a snail’s pace because the building was clearly not designed to accommodate so many people. Obviously this isn’t anyone’s fault, but if you get there and see swarms of schoolchildren you might have picked a bad day. The park and surrounding area is well-worth it otherwise.

Park is amazingly well kept. Historic area. Lots of grounds to walk and explore. After seeing the museum it's a must to decompress a bit. Quite the change from day of detonation. All my respect to the Japanese people who have had to deal with this atrocity.

Humbling reminder of the Human nature.
Beautiful park, a great place to roam around quietly and reflect.
The museum offers vivid depictions on the blast and its consequences. Very graphic. Be mindful, and respectful.

The park is beautiful,  peaceful,  yet the horror and destruction of war is still visible. It's a well maintained place and visited by many tourists. It makes one feel bad to imagine the misery people have gone through, also appreciate how the city has grown from the debris.  Must visit place for everyone.

You can ride the slider for free 😊
I didn't have one, so I was grateful.
There were also protectors that could be attached to helmets and elbows and knees.
There is a point card, and if you collect enough points, you can get a gift 😊
I thought it was amazing that it was free.
There are also paid courses.
The location has been changed to the parking lot and has reopened. The only regret is that there is no toilet.

If there are no events, there will be fewer people and you can practice properly.
I guess it's annoying that there's no tea in the vending machine.

The children's cycle park is open only on Saturdays and Sundays, and you can rent out striders for free, as well as courses with cones and easy slopes. There are about 10 striders. Helmet rentals are also available. All free.
And parking is free.
There are also cribs and a nursing room inside, making it easy to use even with small children. There are also stuffed animals, picture books, slides, and sponge blocks.
Large vinyl playground equipment may not be available depending on the weather. It does not appear to be available in December 2018 due to maintenance.

There is a strider race for preschoolers. It's great that you can play on the fluffy air slide for free and without crowds. The baby's room is also located where the containers are collected, so it's great for families with small siblings. I miss the lady at the restaurant.

I find myself in Hiroshima for business, and today I took the time to visit the place where the devastating atomic bomb was dropped during World War II. Standing at the Hiroshima Peace Memorial Park, surrounded by remnants and memorials of that fateful day, it's impossible not to be deeply moved.
The experience is haunting and sobering. Witnessing firsthand the Atomic Bomb Dome, a skeletal reminder of the destruction unleashed upon this city, brings history to life in a profound way. The museum nearby further amplifies the gravity of what occurred here, displaying artifacts, photographs, and personal accounts that vividly depict the human cost of war.
Walking through the Peace Memorial Park, with its tranquil atmosphere juxtaposed against the weight of its history, is a poignant reminder of the resilience of the human spirit and the importance of pursuing peace. The countless paper cranes, symbols of hope and healing, left by visitors from around the world, underscore the universal desire for a future free from such devastation.
Visiting Hiroshima has been a deeply emotional experience for me. It's a reminder of the consequences of conflict and the imperative to strive for a world where such tragedies are never repeated. The resilience and determination of the people of Hiroshima to rebuild and promote peace serve as an inspiration to us all.

Today, I had the profound opportunity to visit the Hiroshima Peace Memorial Museum. As I stepped into the hallowed grounds, a solemn and pensive atmosphere immediately enveloped me. The sobering photographs, artifacts, and exhibits powerfully conveyed the unimaginable tragedy and human suffering inflicted by the atomic bombing of Hiroshima.

The museum's meticulously curated displays compelled me to deeply reflect on the horrors of war and the incalculable value of peace. Seeing the personal belongings of the victims, learning about their harrowing stories, and witnessing the resilience of the Hiroshima people in the aftermath left an indelible mark on my conscience.

One aspect that struck me during my visit was the sheer number of student groups and tour groups passing through the museum. While it was heartening to see the younger generation engaging with this crucial history, the bustling crowds did at times make it challenging to fully immerse myself in the solemnity of the experience.

My suggestion to future visitors would be to try to allocate sufficient time for their visit, if possible. This hallowed site deserves careful contemplation and reflection. By taking the time to thoughtfully explore the exhibits and exhibitions, one can truly appreciate the gravity of the events that transpired here and be inspired to become a steadfast advocate for peace.

The Hiroshima Peace Memorial Museum stands as a poignant reminder of the devastating consequences of war and the imperative of nurturing a culture of peace. My visit has profoundly shaped my understanding and commitment to this vital mission. I urge all who have the opportunity to visit this site to do so with an open heart and mind, allowing the lessons of the past to guide us towards a future of lasting harmony and nonviolence.

This structure is a grim reminder of massive destruction by the atomic bomb, devastating Hiroshima. Amazingly, the structure itself still stands up, though it is discolored heavily and the interior is pretty much empty, except for the fallen bricks and debris. The area surrounding is beautiful with contrast to the newer infrastructure around. Don’t forget to visit the peace park museum while you are here.

It’s a very surreal experience to visit and see the damage done. You can learn a lot from the things you see and read here. The atmosphere really amplifies the experience as you walk through and observe everything in your surroundings.

I will say this place is almost always filled with tourists and tourist groups. You will, unfortunately, run into disrespectful and unsavory tourists here but I’d like to think by not following my urge to toss one of them into the river, I am keeping the peace this place deserves.

A very stark reminder of the devastation of nuclear war! This place is very special and moving, difficult to display the real atmosphere! Preserved in its ruined state, the structure evokes profound reflection on the impact of the atomic bombing. An absolute must-visit for every person around the World - it is important to understand history and the importance of peace!

We were a group of more than 40 foreigners there, beautiful place and we had fun. Only misunderstanding is, we started playing guitar and singing which authority later explained us that, we are not allowed to do so. This was a bothering experience.
Somtimes it can be a fun place to go, other times there is not much to do. It all Depends on what time of the year you go.

Was an amusement park back in the day, but while te rollercoasters and such are gone, there's still a large kids' pool and many lovely places among the amazing,  Spanish-inspried buildings. Absolutely charming!
A shaved ice place, a curry shop, even a manga library with AC. And the ferry to Etajima, just a short ride across the gorgeous Setonai Sea is also here.
Great cycling pit stop, too, between Kure City and Hiroshima City!
Love it!
It is good for book reading in a a very calm library there; It has parking definitely but a little far from the facility… don’t miss it.

Something of an oddity - Kure Portpia (Portopia?) started life as a theme park, which went out of business, and instead has been turned into a park ran by the local authority. There's a couple of non-vernacular buildings with a sort of mock Mediterranean feel, a few permanent shops, and then occasional events in the grounds - on the day we went there was a market selling pottery. Not exactly on the "must see" list for a visit to Hiroshima, but if you find yourself spending a long time in the area it's a bit unusual, and if nothing else there are nice sea views from here.

This garden is not to be missed. The most beautiful I have visited in Japan in two trips. Photos do not capture the beauty of this garden. Faithfully restored to original layout (off maps, photographs and literature) after most of it was destroyed by the atomic bomb. Being Spring, the pink azaleas were in full bloom and stunning.

You can purchase carp food for ¥100 and the fish are huge and very happy to be fed.

You could easily spend hours in here, meandering the paths, medicinal herb garden, bridges, shrines and bamboo groves. Get the combo ticket with the prefecture art gallery - both are well worth the visit.

A tranquil Japanese garden showcasing the traditional landscape design. For a symbolic entry fee, you can enjoy the meticulously crafted details. Winding paths around the pond, vibrant flora, and historic tea houses. Great place for a brief stop while in Hiroshima!

One of the most beautiful Japanese gardens in Japan. I should qualify this by saying that I have seen fewer than a dozen such gardens in Japan, but even with that caveat I believe that very few places could attain or surpass the exquisite beauty of Hiroshima. The city itself is a superb jewel of a place, nestled into a rugged mountainous coastline, embraced by mountains, trees, rivers, and seas. A place of great natural beauty. The garden in the middle of town not only reflects the overall beauty around it, but enhances it all the more.

Absolutely loved this place! There's a small admission fee but it's totally worth it. There are signs for a path you can follow around the park which does a pretty good job bringing you all around. Probably covers about 80% of the whole.

I would recommend to anyone visiting the area. If you do to peace park you can easily walk to the castle and then come here. Definitely walking distance.

It was beautiful even on a rainy day. Must be gorgeous on a sunny day. It gets quite muddy and a bit slippery so dress accordingly if you are visiting on a rainy day. Although you can see the city in the background, it is so quiet that you almost forget that you are in the middle of the city. Perfect place to wind down after long days of exploration.

I visited this site as it was getting but even then the major areas were lit, so there was no issue in visiting later on.
It's a beautiful sight to see. There's the remains of buildings that are gone and the temple and castle that were both rebuilt.
The castle was not open when I visited but even just walking up to the front entrance is an amazing sight.  You walk across the bridge and through the main gates where you see the remains of the stable and guard house.  You then pass the second bridge and up a path that brings you within view of the temple.
It's an amazing sight with beautiful statues and shrines. There are plaques dotted around with descriptions on each, including what it was and a brief history of it.
There is a further path that takes you past other areas and remains, as well as amenities and brings you to stairs that lead to the entrance to the castle.
The view from the top of the stairs is beautiful both of looking up at the castle but also the surrounding area.

Hiroshima Castle is an absolute gem of historical significance and architectural beauty. Here's why it deserves a perfect rating:

Historical Significance
As a symbol of Hiroshima's rich history and cultural heritage, Hiroshima Castle holds immense significance. Its storied past and resilience in the face of adversity make it a must-visit destination for history enthusiasts and curious travelers alike.

Architectural Beauty
The castle's stunning architecture, characterized by its majestic wooden structure and intricate details, is a sight to behold. From the imposing main keep to the elegant bridges and towers, every corner of Hiroshima Castle exudes charm and grandeur.

Scenic Surroundings
Set against a backdrop of lush greenery and picturesque gardens, Hiroshima Castle offers visitors a serene and tranquil environment to explore. The surrounding moats and cherry blossom trees add to the castle's scenic allure, making it a perfect spot for leisurely strolls and photo opportunities.

Informative Exhibits
Inside the castle grounds, visitors can delve deeper into Hiroshima's history through informative exhibits and displays. From artifacts and artifacts to interactive multimedia installations, these exhibits provide valuable insights into the castle's past and significance.

Accessibility
Located in the heart of Hiroshima city, Hiroshima Castle is easily accessible by public transportation, making it a convenient destination for tourists and locals alike. Its central location also allows visitors to explore other attractions and amenities in the vicinity.

Overall Impression
In summary, Hiroshima Castle is a true cultural treasure that offers visitors a fascinating journey through history, breathtaking architecture, and scenic surroundings. Whether you're a history buff, architecture enthusiast, or nature lover, a visit to Hiroshima Castle is an experience you won't soon forget. Highly recommended.

I just visited this morning and I enjoyed the castle the items inside and the view from the fifth floor. Please be advised there are a little over 100 steps including the first few to enter to get to the top of the fifth floor which has pretty views all around. A cute machine at top floor makes souvenir coins for ¥600 and for ¥30 more you can engrave it. The views of the city were awesome.

A must see when in Hiroshima. Beautifully restored exterior. Modern interior. Fifty percent of the castle interior are museum galleries while the other fifty are just stairs.. all I could remember are the stairs going up to the view deck - not tiring though.. with a beautiful view of the city.

A beautiful historic castle. There are at least 5 floors of stairs to climb. Could be 6 if the lower level was not counted. The view from the top is beautiful. The inside of the castle does have some history. Worth the cost for the view. The grounds are gorgeous and there are bathrooms located outside of the castle.

This is by far the best museum I have ever been to!
The museum has a animation of Hiroshima before and after the bomb blast and it feels so realistic and so heartbreaking.
All the collections of town, stories, facts, artifacts, paintings, photos are well maintained and they sink into your skin.
Also the floor later, which states how Hiroshima came with strategies to come up to be better is very inspiring.
If you visit Hiroshima, never miss this place, it's like walking in a book.

With so much conflict in the world today, a visit to this memorial was a wake-up call to the devastating effect of war.
Every individual should be advocating for peace.
It is truly an inspirational yet emotional place to visit and without a doubt a must do if you visit Hiroshima

This museum was unforgettable— every photo and item exhibited here is emotionally impactful, educational, and thought-provoking. The exhibit does not sugar coat the aftermath of the atomic bomb, so be prepared to see and hear some heart-wrenching photos and stories. The surrounding area, from the Atomic Bomb Dome to the Children’s Peace Memorial to the Flame of Peace, inspires contemplation as well. I highly recommend visiting the area as a wonderful way to spend the greater part of a day.

The outdoor garden is beautiful, and the interior exhibits are well-curated. However, I visited on a weekend, and I found that the space for viewing the exhibits was too cramped for the number of visitors. It was very crowded, which made it difficult to take my time and appreciate the exhibits fully. On the other hand, the ice cream at the museum's cafe was delicious.

Make sure you visit this museum! A very comprehensive look at the devastation caused by the atomic bombing. Its exhibits, including personal artifacts and detailed narratives, provide a deeply moving experience. The museum's focus on peace and nuclear disarmament makes it a vital educational site. A must-see for everyone!

I visited the Hiroshima National Peace Memorial Hall for the Atomic Bomb Victims killed by the USA, and it was a deeply moving experience. Just near, there's a peaceful water basin and the Flame of Peace, which will stay lit until all nuclear weapons are abolished. It’s a place for quiet reflection and a stark reminder of the impact of nuclear warfare.

Free entrance. Could easily missed as the structure is sunken to the ground. Not to be confused with the Hiroshima National Peace Memorial Museum - I did. Very peaceful. The route to the main hall is a downward spiral.

A walk through the harrowing history and reality of the effects of an atomic bomb. A must-see in Japan, this is a heavy place to visit, but much needed for everyone to learn about the atrocities of atomic war from. The museum ticket itself only cost ¥200, but the peace memorial is free to visit. The later you come, the longer the queue for the ticket, so best to book online if coming after midday.

I found the Peace Memorial Hall to be a much more moving and reflective experience than the crowded and noisy Peace Museum. It is easy to miss as it is below ground level. It is free entry and you walk down a winding sloped path to the main memorial. You can sit and quietly reflect while reading the information sheet given to you explaining the design.

The highlight here was a special exhibition on the Akatsuki Corps - the child soldiers that were recruited and trained to be kamakazi boat captains, some as young as 15. I watched a 25 min documentary in a theatre room that had English subtitles. These boys were inscripted towards the end of the war as troop numbers were so low. They were trained to be suicide soldiers. After the bombing in Hiroshima they were redeployed in the rescue and recovery mission and were exposed to many human horrors. The interviews of the now old men and their stories was harrowing.

A good visualization of a significant historical event. You can feel the solemnity in the area. In the museum itself i didn't bother to take pictures because the mood was so heavy.

The ones posted here are from the hall of remembrance.

Going to the top of the Hiroshima Orizuru Tower was a cool experience that the wife and I enjoyed. Not only did we get some nice pictures from the top of the building, but the opportunity to construct our own Origami and drop it on the side of the wall was a lot of fun. There's also a slide that you can get on to make your descent easier, but we decided to walk down so we could appreciate all the different art that's painted on the walls. It is a little expensive to get to the top of the building compared to other attractions, but the experiences that we had here was a fun and unique one.

Very enjoyable, but there isn't a huge amount to see/do for the admission price of 2200 Yen - although some of this admission is donated to good causes like the maintenance of the nearby A-Bomb Dome.

The viewing platform on the top floor is very good and it's open air, so there is a nice breeze. The views are spectacular and you get a clear view of the city and the various sites. On the other floor, there is more information about the A Bomb Dome's architect and it's history, and views of the

There is an optional extra 100 Yen charge for a sheet of origami paper to make into a crane and drop into the collection of nearly 1 million cranes already deposited. This is a good activity and the platform is very high and glass bottomed (not good for people with vertigo!).

The slide down is fun but not the most comfortable experience!

Some shops/stalls make up the rest of the attractions. Overall, this was a nice way to spend an hour but felt a little overpriced.

regular ticket to enter the tower is 2200¥ but these are sold for only until around 17:30. unfortunately we got there too late but were able to go to the rooftop bar only for 1500¥, the viewing platform was basically empty and we were able to enjoy cocktails(alcohol free options also available) and the view. age limit to enter the rooftop bar is 20 years.

I recently had the chance to visit the Hiroshima Orizuru Tower, and I have to say, it was an absolute highlight of my time in the Hiroshima area. This modern architectural gem offers unparalleled views of the city and a unique cultural experience that I won't soon forget. The ticket was a bit pricey tho.

On a clear day, you can see for miles, with the Hiroshima Peace Memorial Park and A-Bomb Dome in the foreground, and the shimmering Seto Inland Sea in the distance. It's an awe-inspiring sight that really puts the scale and beauty of the city into perspective.

But the Orizuru Tower is about more than just the views. There are also several interesting exhibits and interactive experiences that delve into the history and culture of Hiroshima. I especially enjoyed the paper crane folding demonstration, where I learned the proper technique for creating these iconic symbols of peace. It was a humbling and meaningful experience.

The tower also has a lovely cafe and gift shop, where you can enjoy a coffee or tea while soaking in the vistas. And the building itself is an architectural marvel, with its sleek, modern lines and innovative design.

Overall, a visit to the Hiroshima Orizuru Tower is an absolute must for anyone traveling to this resilient and historic city. It offers an unparalleled perspective on Hiroshima, both literally and figuratively. I left with a deep appreciation for the city's past, present, and future. This is an experience I'll always cherish.

This is the only place in Hiroshima where you get to see the Atomic Bomb Dome from above and panoramic view of the entire city and beyond. On the rooftop, there was a member of staff whose relative was a survivor of the bomb attack and she shared some personal stories which were very moving. On the floor below, there were some cool art exhibitions going on and there's a section where you get to learn how to fold an origami crane. Special mention to Nana-san and her colleagues for being very friendly and helpful throughout my stay there :))

1420¥ entrance. Galleries are on the small side BUT the pedigree of the work speaks for itself. All the Western greats of the impressionist school are represented; there’s even a Van Gogh I’ve never heard or seen before, but the Modiglianis and Renoirs were excellent. Who ever bequeathed all this had an excellent eye and all the art felt personally chosen and loved. A very good respite if you need a break from all the history lessons on Hiroshima.

It's not a big museum, I spent around 30 minutes or less to appreciate the art inside. The archistecture of the building is splendid and nice to just sit inside of with its symmetrical shape. It's worth a short pass by to just see. No special exhibits when I came by.

Small but has some great art on display.

Some great 19th century art from eg
Van Gogh, Monet, Manet, Degas.
Location is great and the 4 main rooms are very well set up.

Wheelchair accessible.
Fabulous building displaying some amazing significant works.  Worth spending a few hours here.

In my opinion,  this museum has a unique design.  The building is bright and square.  The entrance to the museum was through the gift shop.  I purchased my ticket and was directed to visit two buildings.  As I walked to the first building,  I noticed the beautiful grounds and the cafe.  The  architecture and landscaping were amazing.   The first building I entered was circular.  There were beautiful pieces on the  walls and individual rooms for the rest of the art.   This museum is so beautifully laid out that you don't have to worry about missing anything.  I saw  works by Van Gogh, Renoir, Monet, Manet, Picasso,  Berthe Morisot, Cezanne, Degas, and so many more.  There was an information card that contained Japanese and English.  The gallery wasn't crowded.  It was very nice and I really enjoyed it.    The next gallery had an exhibition on Alfons Mucha.  It was also beautifully laid out.  I had not heard of this artist before.  I really liked the work.

A lot of nice small models of aeroplanes, ships, cars, trams and trains.
Cars were mostly those super cars. Not many of those old everyday models, which I like most. 200yen ticket for a 65+ coming by train.
Pretty cool museum with lots to do. A but hard to get to without a car but if you don't mind commuting, this is an underrated museum in Hiroshima and I recommend it!

Its okay. Large museum but few exhibits.  On the plus side it is cheap and lots of space for kids to run around. However not many interactive exhibits for kids, lots of models behind glass.  Kids did enjoy riding bicycles outside.  Pay at the vending machine near the information desk. Guides in both japanese and english.  If your in the area stop by, people are nice.

Small transportation museum.

Cheep craft place with friendly and kind volunteer people.

¥510 for an adult and free for children up until junior high school. The models are impressive. Good to combine with the zoo as well.
We had no idea the previous day was a public holiday so we turned up and the museum was closed. Maybe having a list of the dates when it is closed on your website would be a good idea.

The Flame of Peace is a must see while in Hiroshima. A symbol of hope and peace as the world strives to end nuclear arms and move towards unity. The flame has burned continuously since it was lit on the 1st of August, 1964.
The Flame of Peace and it's surrounds are something you must visit whilst in Japan.

A good stop for a photo and a little experience. The flame is a wonderful thing to see, but you do not spend a lot of time there. Usually a line to take a photo and with a lot of tourists. Many of the other things to do in the area this is a nice stop.

Such a great thing to see as you walk to the museum to remind of the need for no more Hiroshima events. The park that surrounds it so peaceful to walk an reflect as you go to the different historical sites near it.
This flame will be switched off once the last Atomic bomb will be dismantled, pretty iconic place to visit on the way to the museum of peace of Hiroshima.

data.formatted_address: 2605 Yukichō Ōaza Tada, Saeki Ward, Hiroshima, 738-0721, Japan
data.name: Hiroshima Yuki Adventures

reviews.text: August 2023 Great family experience (5 people from 11 to 49 years old) in this river, everyone appreciated and benefited from the sensations.

Great place!  Trampoline park with ninja warrior like obstacles, foam pit, slack line, dunk station, and balance surf board.  Price is a little expensive but my family had a blast!  Different areas for kids and adults.  Temps checked at the door and the staff was constantly sanitizing areas and very friendly.  English translation for the online waiver available and they take card.  Parking available in front of building.  We will definitely be back!
Had a blast here. We brought my 2 yr old,  it wasn't the place we were looking for, but had fun anyways.  Definitely for 5yr olds and up. Great time though

Not for small children:
While about 70% of the areas are unavailable for use by toddlers that’s not a problem because the areas for children (under 120cm) are explained beforehand and on the website. What isn’t explained is that in the areas where small kids and parents can play together they actually can’t. They have to play on separate trampolines. Which is somehow considered safer. But, in the unlikely event your child does get into trouble, too deep in the sponge pool for example, then you are permitted to stretch over and try to rescue them, ( just, for the love of god, don’t step on “their” trampoline). The most fun looking area is where children can climb up a net maze and slide down into a pool of sponges. However, parents aren’t even allowed in this area, toddlers reach out for their parents who are behind the netting to help them climb but alas they’re not allowed in so the child just gives up and comes out. Presumably if a child does make it halfway through the maze and starts crying the parent would have to coax the child back down with a Pocky from beyond the netting and if that were to fail then  you’re in for the long haul,  curl up with a good book and wait, for “you must not step beyond the netting!!” Quite bizarre.
Their quest for the ultimate safe trampolining environment is commendable although when I pointed out to staff there were overlapping mats which caused my child to trip the staff member said “yes, i noticed it too it’s been this way since April but the company refuse to fix it!” And in case you’re wondering if fixing the mats would require closing the place while trampoline engineers come in to manage the situation, they’re an inch thick and stuck down with Velcro.
Rather than wait for them to adopt a sensible communal play area policy, I’ve decided to give it a miss until my child hits the magic 120cm.
The Outlets trampoline area for 3yrs and over is much more sensibly arranged just jump around and have a laugh for a fraction of the price. And if you bash your bum on someone else’s knee, dry your eyes and get jumpy!

I had a great time here with my girlfriend! There's a lot of activities to do here. The regular trampoline padded area, with the slope walls and a center piece to do kongs or whatnot over. 2 balance tests, a surf board type deal, and a balance belt. There's 2 foam pits to jump into. 2 basketball hoops. A high jump. And even some small scale Ninja Warrior courses!

Dudes need to get their pro area fixed! They doubled layered the pro tramp to kill the bounce. Nobody jumps on it, complete waste, disappointed.  Everything else is great, lots of pretty college girls too

Honestly one of the most beautiful temples I’ve ever been to and I’ve seen many. It’s quite hidden and there are not many people going there, also mostly locals, so not as touristy as other ones.
I also highly recommend hiking up the mountain or going into the forest a little bit it’s a very nice view from up top, took like 1-1,5h and is a quite easy hike (feels like 3/10)

One of the most beautiful temple I’ve ever seen. The wooden structures are built within the rocks on the mountain which creates an incredible atmosphere.

Whilst you’re there I recommend hiking to the top of the mountain as you’ll have several unforgettable scenic spots looking over Hiroshima. If you do though, be aware that the temple close at 5pm so make sure to be back by then.

This is a magical place of great peace and serenity. Loved it to bits. There's a kind old lady next to the temple selling charms and providing information for visitors. You throw the entrance donation into a wooden box with 5 openings. I'd visit again!
Beautiful temple in the hills just outside Hiroshima, we worth the walk to get here. The temple is spread over a hillside with many steps. Very tranquil, with waterfalls.
The entire temple is full of serenity and harmony.  One of the best I have seen in Chukogu. Highly recommended.
Finally a place to swim and do squats for less than 500 yen! Hell damn fart, that's a steal!

Since last week, I have been using the pool to practice swimming and relieve my lack of exercise.
Other people's reviews said that the building was old, and the changing rooms at the swimming school I went to when I was a child had a strange odor that I can still remember, so I was reluctant to try the indoor pool. However, the changing room here is cleaner than I expected, and I don't really mind the smell, and the pool is sunny and has a bright atmosphere, so I can use it very comfortably!
However, although the pool is divided into free courses, swimming courses, and walking courses, I had some trouble understanding the structure and rules of the courses, but the usage fee is reasonable at less than 500 yen. , I think I'll repeat it because it's close to my house.

I had to go to the pool for a limited time, so I came here for the first time in a billion years since it was the closest to my home. I called ahead of time to find out what was required (swimming suit and swimming cap). Now that I think about it, I used to come here often when I was in elementary school. That's quite a history! I will be using it from time to time. The bypass has been completed and the traffic on Route 2 has decreased, so you can get there quickly!

Supporting junior high school students in competitions.
Are the audience seats on the main side? It is only open to the public and is very crowded and difficult to see.
The court is clean and provides a very good environment for the players. Close to the station and convenient

I used it at the pool. 490 yen per use, locker 100 yen. For those who go a lot, we also sell 11 tickets for 10 times.
There is one lane for walking, one lane for swimming 50 meters, two lanes for swimming 25 meters, and one lane that can be used freely by children and for walking and swimming. There is also a smaller shallow pool for small children.
There are guards in small rooms in the middle and in the corners.
There is one shower.

The Clock Tower of Peace in Hiroshima's Peace Memorial Park stands as a silent observer of time, marking the moments since the tragic events of August 6, 1945. Every day, the clock chimes at 8:15 AM, the exact moment the atomic bomb was dropped on Hiroshima, serving as a somber reminder of the event that forever changed the course of history.

The tower, with its elegant and minimalistic design, doesn't just count hours but underscores the value of every second in the pursuit of peace. Its daily chime transcends a mere reminder of the past; it's a call to action, urging us to use our time wisely, work towards a peaceful world, and ensure such tragedies are never repeated. As the hands move, the Clock Tower of Peace beckons us to move forward with purpose and hope.
Nice tower, not much to see beyond that
A tall artistic monument found on the northern tip of the park just before the T-bridge.
A monument to remind us of how badly we can behave and of the hope that we can change to become more peaceful creatures. Thank you to the people that care such wonderful care of these grounds.
It recalls the effect of the atomic bomb which bent the most resistant metal structures.

In Hiroshima, which was reduced to ashes by the atomic bombing, there were naturally no homes to live in.
Mr. Schmoe came to Japan from the United States in 1945 and built 21 houses himself, which were used as municipal housing and made people happy. I was surprised that something like this happened.
And it's even more surprising that it's not even known to Hiroshima citizens now.
The Schmoe House is located a little further back from the street, and there are no information boards nearby, so there are very few visitors, which is a shame.
From that perspective, this place is a hidden gem.
There are no notable tourist facilities in the vicinity other than Ebayama Park, but the Eba district has been a fishing village since the Edo period and has many alleys, so why not take a stroll around it?

reviews.author_name: デグスビィ主教（髭熊調教師）
reviews.text: This is a small museum located at the southern foot of Mt. Eba Sarayama. There is an exhibit about the achievements of Floyd Schmoe and others who worked hard to support the reconstruction of Hiroshima immediately after WW2.
The view from Shumo House is a sunrise spot.

A meeting place built by American forest scientist Floyd Shumo for atomic bomb survivors.
It is said that a total of 21 buildings were built.

I pass by it once a day, but only go inside when the exhibits change, about once a year. The exhibits don't change much, but they are much more interesting! The house was built in the post-war period when there was nothing left, so you can see a different structure from today.Please come and visit us! ️.

The place is not big but it’s free of charge.

I went there on a rainy day, so there were only me and another guy there. The lady who was in charge of the museum was very kind to me. She offered me some tissue paper to wipe my shoes because it was wet due to the rain, and she also asked if I have umbrella before I left.
Free to visit. This is a piece of history from real event which takes us back in time. Worth a quick visit to read about what happened at the school and some survivors’ stories. It was surreal.

Very interesting museum and a must see.

However a very old an grumpy man sitting in the reception, be careful. The only person I have met in Japan for three weeks who hasn’t been nice.
Small museum with many things available in English. I really got the sense of the hardship and suffering the bomb caused.
A very unique and humbling experience. The little old man at the entrance was very sweet.
I visited this place during a holiday. There are two ways to get here. The architecture inside is beautiful. The area is quiet and full of nature and buildings that blend well together.

MOCA allowed me to absorb the history of Hiroshima from an aesthetic millieu that helped me grasp the heart of the community and its reinvention in a unique way.

Placed a bit off in nature, elevated by mountain energy, the journey getting to the museum itself helps a traveler have a breather, and an aerial view from which to take in Hiroshima city and its surrounds.

Part of the exhibition is always changing so it's definitely a place to visit and revisit.

The collection of art is relevant, hosting a variety of local and international wonders.

This was one of my top favorite places on my sojourn. Recommend.

Newly reopened in 2023 after 2 years of renovation & the first exhibit until 6/18 is documenting the process of renewal and the things they kept, updates and how they carefully moved the artwork before and moved it back after.
Fantastic outdoor sculpture to explore and lovely tree-filled spaces all around.
Cafe is also lovely and sources from local farmers, bakers and fruit shops for a sustainable and high-quality focus on health and support of local Economy as well as less use of plastics and single-use waste than a typical cafe. Vegan and vegetarian friendly as well as a pairing suggestion with wine for each dish and intro of local producers in a stylish mag menu.
Barrier free wheelchair and stroller accessible.

hiroshima moca is located on the top of the small mountain.
after appreciating the arts (which are pretty good), you still can walk around in the green. very relaxing place.

Beautifully, modern art museum located in the middle of a hilltop park. We had limited time before our train back to Tokyo, but we were able to absorb the best parts in about 45 minutes and have a great breakfast at the connecting cafe.

This was a perfect companion to the Peace Museum, and the museum does an excellent job of explaining their mandate and role in the arts.

data.name: Hiroshima City Museum of History and Traditional Crafts

reviews.text: Nice Place to get very broad idea about Hiroshima culture and back born of Hiroshima. specially people who staff in his museum is very kind and helpful. One disadvantage is whole thing explain in Japanese only you can have small English Leaflet.

This museum has quite an attractive way to display and inform visitors (as any museums in japan). Using images, real property, ship model, non-japanese can quite understand the history of japanese civilization (there is a wall with images of progression of japanese civilization) and also indigenous skill and agricultural or pottery craft just by seeing the materials displayed. Although if non-japanese person would want to understand more detail, a good knowledge of hiragana + google translator + gadget's search engine will surely help
A very nice museum with some cool pieces of history. Very cheap and very small, but the price-to-size ratio is more than worth it!
Lovely museum but not intended for tourists. Recommended!
It's industry Provence mesuem which was used in olden Japanese people including farming, war and home appliance
This small museum is such a nice place to visit.  It show the life of a writer. Even Has a tree that survived the bomb.
Very small museum (two main rooms), but the staff was incredibly friendly. I had a private tour with two different staff and they did their best for me to fully enjoy my experience.
I need air conditionerrr!!!

Go to Sanyo Rai's Words of Joy, Anger, Sorrow, and Happiness Exhibition
I liked the exhibition that divided letters and letters from this era into various emotions, anger, sadness, and happiness.
In particular, Sanyo's letter to his son was probably sad, but I don't remember it clearly.
I was shaken by a line that tells us to stop and look around us, even in the most glorious moments. During the Edo period, he loved everyday life, wrote down every moment, and acknowledged even his imperfections. number of letters
Seasonal flowers, the sky, and the other person's movements
It was an exhibition where you can see the personality from the letters.
I was curious about it, so I'm glad I was able to go.
I didn't know anything about this scholar, so I visited this museum during my trip to Hiroshima and learned a lot of things.Even though it's small, it's rich in content.
Experience was great. Score 0-0 not so. It was glorious summer evening to enjoy some baseball.
Amazing Gallery, 2nd floor just above the stadium shop.

Great Hiroshima Carp store

I liked the variety of items offered celebrating  this beloved baseball powerhouse.

I was sorry the XL sizes  (or LL in Japan) were very limited, but there are so many other  souvenirs to choose from.
Good spot to buy Hiroshima Carp tickets. My suggestion is to buy ahead now though, as they sell out now that they're good. GO CARP!
Hiroshima carp gallery, we can buy official shops here. And in 2nd floor, it has memorial goods here.

Awesome museum with tons of history. There is a bunch of sections written in English underneath Japanese text. Easily spent 3 hours walking around and also seeing the Aircraft Carrier exhibit

Just a minor complaint: There is an Augmented Reality app you can download that will help with navigating, but it has too many issues on Android.

A wonderful museum that not only tells the story of the battleship Yamamoto but also tells the story about Kure as a port and shipyard. A very facinating museeum.
Kure has a long and solid history as a port and shipyard, which the museum illustrates well.
It's a deep dive into a city and region, and part of Japan's complex maritime history.
.. and then the model of Yamato. It must be seen and experienced with your own eyes.
Something as large and impressive as this model probably had to be created to in turn illustrate the grandiose Yamato.
If you like military history or ships, then this is the place for you. There is also an interactive area on the top floor for children to learn about ships, that your kids will love.

Great museum and more then just a model of the Yamato. They had lots of artifacts from the sunken ship and lots of pictures of the ship. They explained the building of the ship and the sailing of the ship. Great museum and I recommend going.

Went here and the submarine museum. Both were great. Going in the submarine in the submarine museum was very good. At the Yamato museum, the models are interesting but they have made it more interesting for you get kids with more interactive features on the third floor. Hopefully when it undergoes renewal there will be more like this. It's also only 500 yen for adults so it is nicely priced.

data.formatted_address: 3-1 Shinchi, Fuchu, Aki District, Hiroshima 735-0028, Japan
data.name: MAZDA Museum

reviews.text: Amazing experience to learn about Mazda! Seeing the 787B that won the 1991 LeMans was definitely a highlight. I highly recommend this if you’re visiting Hiroshima. Make sure to book a reservation in advance or else you won’t be able to do the tour! (free entry as well)

Really enjoyed our visit to the Museum today. We hadn't booked the tour but walked in and were allowed to join the next English tour 50 mins later. But I suggest you book first as we just got lucky. The assembly line alone is well worth the visit, so cool to see!

For Mazda car users, it is very appropriate to visit the museum where various Mazda car models are assembled (photos or video clips are prohibited inside the car assembly plant). It will give you an idea of ​​the outstanding performance and safety of the cars.  In this regard, it is also comparable to driving a high-quality European car on a budget that is not too expensive and is worth it.

Cool experience for anyone interested in Mazda as a brand or car manufacturing in general.

Free tour offered in English; you just have to sign up through their website in advance (sign-ups open 30 days before the desired tour date).

The museum was neat to see display models (some of which you can interact with/try out, others are interesting for historical significance - like the Mazda 787B Le Mans 1991 championship vehicle).

Our favourite part was getting to walk the factory floor and see vehicles being assembled behind the scenes (just a heads up: no photos allowed for that portion of the tour though).

The gift shop was cute and had some limited edition Mazda keepsakes/accessories, but it was a lot smaller than we were expecting.

Would definitely recommend if you are in Hiroshima and at all curious about Mazda!
Incredible FREE tour at the Mazda Factory. Book online in advance. Excellent guide, great cars and information. 2.15-4.15pm.

data.formatted_address: Japan, 〒733-0833 Hiroshima, Nishi Ward, Shōkō Center, 7-chōme−4−５ ＷｏｏｄＥｇｇお好み焼館
data.name: WoodEgg OKONOMIYAKI MUSEUM

reviews.text: Book in advance to do hands-on cooking of making the okonomiyaki. Museum and showroom is free to walk-in. Lots of sauces to buy.

Had a wonderful time here learning to make Hiroshima style okonomiyaki as well as learning the history of the origins of Otafuku.  The lobby staff took our photos with some props outside of the primary entrance (not pictured) and showed us where to begin our class.

The class was very fun.  It seems that they provide English translators if asked (a couple near us had a staff member translating near us), though I am unsure if you need to ask for one ahead of schedule as my wife acted as my translator.  The primary teacher performed the full process for us, explaining what she was doing step by step.  After her demonstration, you get to cook your own okonomiyaki on a hotplate, with provided instructions.  Staff members were always around to provide guidance.

After our class, we were taken on a tour of the Otafuku museum and factory.  The museum contained educational material about the start of Otafuku.  At the factory, we were able to see the various bottles being processed as well as the packaging and shipping area.  At the conclusion of the tour, we were all handed a bottle of Takoyaki sauce hot off the factory floor.

After the class and tour, you are given the opportunity to purchase supplies for making your own dishes at their store.  Overall, a great experience learning about Okonomiyaki and the Otafuku company.  Definitely recommended if you visit Hiroshima!

Amazing, most hospitable! We arrived very early for our reserved cooking class, and they graciously gave us a museum and factory tour despite not having a reservation for the latter. Tour guide was very kind, spoke good english and everyone seemed genuinely excited we were visiting!

Class was great and we made some very tasty okonomyaki. The head chef did not speak much english, but two of his assistants spoke some and we understood through gestures. They have a showroom (giftshop) where you can purchase their products and logo merchandise (they'll engrave what you want in a spatula!). A unique and can't miss Hiroshima experience! Borderless happiness!

This is the only place gave me great impression after visiting many tourist spots.
The receptionist was very attentive and hospitable.  The entire atmosphere was welcoming and clean.

Can I give it half a star!?
The worst museum to go to.
Interesting history
Thank goodness free!
Not worth your time at all
Go eat the dish instead
Don't go just google the history instead

Wonderful museum with preservation of Miyajima history and the impact of the island on Japan and overseas, many artifacts and art to see too. English and Japanese descriptions available. The first floor of the museum was the home of a wealthy merchant, fun to walk around and view the garden while enjoying the architecture.

Also if you are a stamp collector, there is a stamp by the admission booth. There is space on the back of your ticket for the stamp as well.

This museum is a jewel in the island a Must to visit.
It looks like a simple beautiful classic japanese house from the outside, on the inside it begins like a modest place showing some history and instruments used on the island.
Then it has a second floor with more history like a normal museum but what bring this place on top of most places is that it provides you the chance to go inside the house and seat in the living room, try to do some Japanese Origami, heard the little fountain on the garden of the house and feel what could have been living in a place like that on the old days, absolutely gorgeous.
I highly recommend to visit this place.

It is worth to see inside. Photo were not allow for building A, B,C, and D. Some area, we must take off our shoes. We have to follow the direction arrow for viewing. We can see many old stuffs which were used in old time. The traditional house in Miyajima also display.
Much more to this museum than you might think from the street. Multiple buildings and exhibits, and a section with shoes not allowed near the end. Well worth the low price!
Very interesting to learn about old house, history of the island and the shrine. It’s worth to visit.

data.formatted_address: Japan, 〒737-0029 Hiroshima, Kure, Takaramachi, 5−３２ 海上自衛隊呉史料館
data.name: Japan Maritime Self-Defense Force (JMSDF) Kure Museum

reviews.text: Choose to visit Kure? Must come here. This museum is FREE ADMISSION with history on the JMSDF, minesweepers and a look inside a submarine so you can get a taste of what it feels like inside. There is lots of parking around the site, and a walk from Kure JR railway station. There are many models of submarines, helicopters, and explosives, as well as the parts making up them.

Possibly one of the best free things you can do in the Kure area. The JMSDF museum is free admission, with an English info booklet and on some of the displays. From the production of mines, the Japanese Navy involvement with international projects and even a tour on one of their Submarines. The place is usually not busy, but often there are groups of students once in a while. The staff are present on every floor, for assistance and security if the displays. There's also some interactive content like peering through binos, climbing and resting in a cabin, as well as a photo booth. There's a lot to do here, plus a gift shop at the end of the museum. I recommend visiting the JMSDF museum.

Didn't actually know about this one. But once you reach the Yamato museum you can't miss the hint. -Yes they put the biggest map mark in front of it I've ever seen!
Besides of seeing a real sub from the inside it offers a lot about the recent defence forces and mine sweeping.
-Did I already mention the real sub in front of it?
Worth a visit. And. You need to see it to believe it. All exhibits are well presented, preserved. All employees of the museum is very friendly and courteous.

I will definitely bring my mother here even just for the submarine and then she can tell that she was aboard on one.

Also the exhibitions were very informative and the temporary exhibition about the Antartic expeditions... Those crochet penguins got me well.

Very sad but very important place for humanity.  A beautifully prepared exposition with the history before and especially after the event.  Everything is described in multiple languages.  Very instructive.

This place holds historical objects that are witnesses of the tragic atomic bombing in the tragic city of Nagasaki. There are also photos and videos of facts from that time. Being here really make me feels the deep sadness of innocent people who have become victims of war. I hope more people support the peaceful program

I went on a weekday afternoon and there were very little people.
The museum shows the haunting aftermath of the bombing of Nagasaki. It's walking distance to the park but you will have to climb some stairs on your way back.

This is one of the most spine chilling experiences I have had. I study this in history books, I have watched documentaries, movies and seeing it in person and being on ground zero is another level experience. It is a must when in Nagasaki! Let's hope that we have learned from this experience
one of the must see places in Nagasaki. there you will discover the details of what had happened when the city was hit by the atomic bomb. was teary eyed in the end.

data.formatted_address: Peace Memorial Park - Hiroshima, 1 Nakajimachō, Naka Ward, Hiroshima, 730-0811, Japan
data.name: Hiroshima Victims Memorial Cenotaph

reviews.text: A special place in remembrance of victims from the Hiroshima bombing incident. Within this Cenotaph contains names of all the known victims from the bombing incident. The memorial is intentionally build in such a shape so as to shelter these innocent living beings. I learnt from the tour guide, the cenotaph is engraved with the words “ Let all the souls be rest in peace, for we shall not repeat the evil”. 🙏🙏

This peaceful memorial is beautifully carved out and right at the center of the Piece Park. Of course rected to those who suffered from the atomic bomb attack. The stone is also perfectly aligned with the flame and the Dome in the background. Overall a well placed memorial to remember the fallen.

A memorial dedicated to the victims of the atomic bombing. Inside the tomb contains the names of all those killed. The concrete saddled shaped monument represents a shelter for the souls of the victims. It is aligned with the Peace Flame and the Atomic Dome.
A place to pay your respects, pray, remember the dead and hope for a better tomorrow 🕊

In the centre of the Peace Park you can find the Hiroshima Victims Memorial Cenotaph. The memorial was rected for all the victims of the atomic bomb drop over Hiroshima in 1945. If you look through the Cenotaph you can see the cenotaph is aligned with the peace flame and the Genbaku Dome.

data.name: Monument in Hiroshima Prefecture Employment Security administrative atomic bomb martyr's requiem

reviews.text: Went there by my electric bicycle, not too difficult to go to the mountain top. Viewpoint has great view of Hiroshima’s cityscape and harbor. Not to mention there are plenty of stray cats if you are a cat lover.

A very nice place for night sightseeing.
But somehow difficult to arrive if you can't go on foot or drive.
whole 360 view of Hiroshima city..
also be carful it's windy on the top of terrence.

The Somei Yoshino cherry trees are not yet in bloom, but the Kanhi cherry blossoms are in bloom. It's well maintained, so it's nice to see the scenery from the observation deck!

2024.3.16

You can reach the top by car.

There is a large plaza and a small plaza, so you can enjoy both as you can see the scenery from different angles.

The road is relatively wide, but there are parts where there are no sidewalks, so please be careful of pedestrians and bicycles.

Please note that the area is closed to vehicles between 11pm and 5am, and police cars are patrolling the area, so please be careful if you are going at night.

April 5th: 60% to 70% of the cherry blossoms had fallen.
The weather was nice so the cat
It was relaxing😊
The observation deck has been updated, so even if the cherry blossoms are gone, you can still enjoy the view on sunny days ✌️😊

data.formatted_address: Japan, 〒730-0028 Hiroshima, Naka Ward, Nagarekawachō, 8−２０ 流川エイトビル 地下１階
data.name: Nightclub【LAGOON HIROSHIMA】

reviews.text: Great place! Now that it’s Lagoon the music is awesome. Best actual night club in Hiroshima
Very cool. It is down a flight of stairs.  The setup is very organized and well thought out. Can't wait to come back for the night life.

It wants to look like a Club, but it looks disgusting.  The floor is super sticky, there is non-stop smoking and a super pungent smell, and many customers are not dressed appropriately for a fancy Club.  A lot of drunks, you have to be careful that at any time someone can spill drink on you and another problem, fights and brawls happen very quickly.
And the problem with taking a photo of the ID, it's kind of weird.
It is the most disgusting Club seen so far.  I can't believe that I'm Japan in 2023, there is such mentality and such Club trash.

The place seems nice but was completely empty at 23:30 the day before a national holidays (so not on weekend).
Also the entrance is bit pricey. 2500¥ without any drink.
That said it was a week day in July 2021, so maybe worth to try on a weekend.

I do not recommend to people who respect themselves!  It's not a Club, it's a Club dump, full of unwashed people, as is the club floor.  They smoke a lot because of the lack of occupation, and the smell is very pungent.  I can't believe that in 2023 in Japan people smoke indoors.  Many boys, men, come to harass girls who are drunk and some do it very aggressively.  The fights are on the list, be careful those who visit this garbage.
Be careful about when you decide to go up here. We paid around 12000 yen and over 2 hours of our time to see a blur through mist.
Drive up was a bit sketchy but not nearly as bad as some mountain roads can be. Views were absolutely stellar even before sunset, and as the city lit up it got even more gorgeous.

The view from the top at night is stunning, but it’s really not worth the ride at night. This place is not exactly a tourist attraction, so don’t be surprised if you don’t see any cars or humans on your way to the top. I got a taxi for 10,000 yen which is a bit too much for the experience in return.

This is one of the most amazing views I have seen in all of Japan. HOWEVER, please know this. The road going up to this observation deck is EXTREMELY dangerous. It is about 15 km long. The first 5 km are well paved, two-lane roads. Then the next 5 km, the road turns into one lane and gets increasingly narrow and steep. The last 5 km are the most dangerous of all. The road is so narrow that there were times I thought our car would fall of the edge of the mountain. At many points along the road there was no guard rail whatsoever. The paved road turned into dirt, and we were constantly running over leaves, sticks, and rocks. The view is worth the drive, but PLEASE be careful. Only the most experienced of drivers should try it.
Excellent place to see the night view of kure city
The perfect landscape, you need to come and admire the view. Day or night, it is a beautiful view to behold; amazing Japan!
Great 😊 Hiroshima
Great view of Hiroshima, worth the drive!
satisfied! nice place especially for couple.
Show🗺🌅

data.formatted_address: 4 Chome-16 Kanonshinmachi, Nishi Ward, Hiroshima, 733-0036, Japan
data.name: Kannon Marina Seaside Park

reviews.text: Rodw my bike here from the a-bomb dome. Not a very long ride and it's fairly flat. The park is quite small but the view is lovely, you can see miyajima island from it

So much to do, amusement, dining, relaxing. View the Marina from a nice restaurant. Indulge in your hobbies at the many shops. Or just kick back the dingy launch port and park. Either way, it's gonna be fun.
I guess it's a little out of the way, but you can get a beautiful view of the water from here and it's a nice place to sit and enjoy a peaceful night.
Looking for prayer space near Marina hop while enjoying the seaside? Obviously you can come to this place. It is near to marina hop and accessible. But don't forget to bring your own prayer mat 👍🏻

This is a park located a little further into Mariho. This is a park where you can enjoy the beauty of the Seto Inland Sea and the islands including Miyajima. Although it's not a big park, there is a Mariho nearby, so it's a great place to relax.

data.formatted_address: Japan, 〒730-0028 Hiroshima, Naka Ward, Nagarekawachō, 7−６ 第五白菱ビル 3階
data.name: club G hiroshima

reviews.text: We been there last week with my coworkers we have so much fun,especially thanks to g club staff for their honesty😊  I lost my EarPods demo kaeshitekureta arigatou,matta ikimasu.merry Christmas 🤶

Good club with a bit of vibe. On my night the DJ kept switching the songs and even subgenres too often. If you are a newbie to clubs this is OK. If you want to get into the flow - no way. From my experience, local place to get locals hookup :-) not bad, but not good.

This place is a late-night hip-hop/rap dance club. Every time I've been here, it was mostly full of American off-duty military men (presumably from Iwakuni) and a handful of Japanese and Philipino women. It gets busy late, and can be totally packed at 5am on a Saturday morning, but if you dare stay that late, be prepared for the grossness that is the dancefloor after dozens of people have spilled their drinks on it. Some people here have serious dance moves, and obviously take it very seriously. Others however, see it as a reliable hook-up spot. Overall, it's a little immature for my tastes, and I'd guess the average age of the regular patrons around 25.
This is a dance club. Gets very busy after midnight, small bar, one toilet.  Go here to dance not drink or talk. Cover 2000 yen good for one drink token. Ladies generally free or reduced.
Club G one of the littest clubs in Hiroshima, after visiting Japan after 5 years theyre still making fun nights

Aioi T bridge is a 3 way bridge built in 1932 on the Ota river near the confluence of Hankawa river and Motiyasu river. This bridge was the zero point for 3rd August 1945 atomic bombing. The actual point of bombing was 800 metres away but significant damage was,caused to the bridge.
We visited this bridge during our Hiroshima tour. The T shape of the bridge is quiet unique. You can stroll on the pathways on its sides and take photos of the Atomic Park beside the bridge.

This is the view from the bridge. The bridge is an unusual T-shaped three-way bridge that connects to the Peace Memorial Park. Since the bridge was so easily recognisable from the sky, and been in the center of the city, it was used by the bomber plane as the visual aiming point for the atomic bomb back in 1945.

At least we know the bomb came from Durango and Silverton Colorado. Combined by their river, the Animus. Womanly hate. Arrhgg. Maa.
That's why 2 cities.
Chicken 🐔 and Cow 🐄!!!!!!!
What a memorial. Yes. Mueah
It's basically just a bridge, but also it's a good starting point for a tour of all the a-bomb related sites, which are close by. The bridge was the target point for the 1945 bombing.

This bridge was the planned target for atomic bomb and would have been the hypocenter. However the bomb actually exploded away from it. This bridge was severely damaged but it was repaired and used for a while before it was entirely replaced by a new built to resemble the original

data.formatted_address: Japan, 〒730-0028 Hiroshima, Naka Ward, Nagarekawachō, 3−６ ローリング流川 8F
data.name: Tropical Bar Revolución

reviews.text: Great atmosphere of locals and tourists. Go to the top floor in the elevator! Board games and a large choice of drinks, reasonable prices! Had so much fun, barman is very welcoming.

Great place for a cocktail or beer. Bear in mind that it’s up on 8th floor accessible by a tiny lift. The bar tender ( the man with the Che Guevara beret) is a warm, funny and chatty guy and is very welcoming into this small bar with intimate lighting. A wide range of cocktails beer and wine is available at reasonable prices and there is a balcony for you to get a view of the streets below. Enjoy the vibe of this great little place.
Here you can have fun and drinks! Good place to have some drink and meet new people. The owner is a  funny cheerful guy.

When I found the bar, there was a bunch of young foreigners standing downstairs. One guy decided to check the bar. He let me enter first but quickly left, obviously disliking the spot.

However, I loved the place. Most of the customers are locals. The host speaks English and shared interesting experience of travels, including Russia.

Cocktails are tropical, rum-based, but can order something else. A nice shelter from the busy routine downstairs. Remember, the bar is on the 8th floor, which is cool.

If I could I would give it 6 stars.  the owner speaks English and is very friendly.  The atmosphere is good and simple.  There is a balcony.  The bar is on the 8th floor.  I highly recommend you take a look there.
Wonderful ambience. I thought it would be a busy day since i went there on a weekend. But it turned out to be not.
Very beautiful view from the top. Nice place to camp if you are bicycle touring

When you go up the stairs, there is a large open space.
