There were slides, jungle gyms, seesaws, swings, etc.
There is also a restroom.
Perhaps because there is no parking lot, there were few people and it was quiet even on a Saturday day.
Miyajima could also be seen from the top of the mountain.

The park was created by carving out a mountain, so it is rich in nature, and you can see beautiful views from the top of the mountain.

I could hear the cries of warblers coming from various places.

It's surrounded by nature and there aren't many people around, so some people may be concerned about spider webs, but that's part of the charm.

There is a lot of play equipment, and although it is hard to tell, there is also something that looks like a tennis or volleyball court.

I usually stop by on the walking course. It will be a bit of exercise to get to the top of the mountain.
We also come here to view the cherry blossoms every year. It's a beautiful cherry blossom!
There is a tennis court, some play equipment, and restrooms. There is a nice view at the top of the mountain.

Location is good. Right at Hiroshima station, so you can easily go to/from the airport as well as to Miyajima Island or anywhere else in Hiroshima.

Room is spacious, clean, with plenty of amenities in the room. The cleaning staff are friendly and provide any supplies you need. Wifi is also fast for working.

The only reason I didn't like my stay was because the receptionists are not friendly. They didn't seem happy about any of my requests. I asked for 2 rooms keys instead of 1 - the receptionist told me I'd get 1 only and hesitated to finally give me 2. I asked for toilet paper at 4am because I work throughout the nighttime, the receptionist said I can only get it at 7am, but eventually decided to give it to me.

Besides the receptionists, the other staff throughout the lobby are all friendly with smiles.

GREAT hotel! Very clean and nice, room was great and stocked with amenities, location at the train station was very convenient. Breakfast was the one thing I didn’t enjoy. It was a very crowded and the whole layout was a bottleneck. The selection was great but none of the food was very good,  except for maybe the pastries and espresso. After staying at a crappy Airbnb in Osaka the night  before, it was really nice to stay in such a nice hotel. I loved Hiroshima, overall, and would have liked to stay for another night or two.

Very 5* look and feel from the moment you step into the atrium and this feeling holds during the whole stay. Staff speaks English well, so check-in process went smoothly and check-out was even easier since you can just put the room card into the check-out machine. I booked a smoking room by mistake and there was no non-smoking room available for the two nights I was stying there, but the staff cleaned the room so well, I didn't notice any smell. Speaking of the room, it it's clean, relatively spacious and has an actual storage space for clothes. Bathroom was also perfect lying clean with bathtub large enough for me to have comfortable bath. There are multiple restaurants with two of them also serving breakfast. Dish Parade is a buffet-style with an incredible range of options to choose from and they list the allergens by most of the meals, so it will be great for people with dietary restrictions. I went to there both mornings and never experienced any wait time. And lastly about the location - the seconds floor is directly connected to Hiroshima station, so you literally cannot be closer to the station.

Very convenient, 3 minutes walk to Hiroshima train station and plenty of restaurants and shops nearby. Room is clean and staff is very helpful, speaks some English. Only thing is there is no coin laundry machine in the hotel, they do offer laundry service is prohibitively expensive. You can walk 10 min to a laundry coin service though.
Best location at the Hiroshima Station. The Bar time was fantastic to have a couple of drinks before dinner. It is complimentary. We enjoyed our stay.

Amazing...
The Best cycling Adventure...
The view during the day is spectacular, and the night view is also very beautiful. The road is well maintained and easy to get to, and there is a parking lot and restroom at the observation deck.

The summit in the daytime after a long time
At 3pm on November 12th, Kure Port is directly backlit.
Strawberry moon, Kure town, and Setouchi are the best!

Haigamine is nice to see from the city, but when you actually go there, it has a gloomy current, day and night. Honestly, it's better to stay away from this area.
That's why I gave it 5 stars.

I booked here having stayed at Mitsui Gardens Roppongi. So I expected more. Unfortunately the hotel and rooms were outdated. The shower sprayed to the far end of the bathtub/shower and was not adjustable so it was hard to shower only having a small space to catch the water. It was very dirty, mould in ceiling, stains and marks on walls. The pillows were awful, very flat and had some sort of beans in them? The staff however were absolutely amazing, accommodating and extremely helpful. The location was great. I have much respect for this city for what they have been through and the strength to rebuild so quickly is admirable.

Hotel was renovated by the looks of it. Great location, within walkable distance to the Peace Memorial Park.

Ventilation in-room was a problem though. First night when we arrived the room had literally no air flow. We had to borrow a fan from the hotel to get over the night. Some other guests had to leave their door open to get some air in.

Hotel interior was renovated recently but not the bathroom. It looked old. We 2 were assigned a room with a double bed but it was apparently designed for 1 person use so there was hardly any space for us to use.
They had outstanding amenities. The topmfloor lounge has so many free treats and drinks and great views. And even their paid breakfast is outstanding. Really loved this stay.

If you get a room high up the view is sublime. We stayed at floor 22 and the price was about $100 a night for two people including breakfast, which was great! The view from the top lounge was insane 360 view, also there was free wine...

It's a great location, the staff are helpful and the views are awesome. But this place has a big problem, it's impossible to get any fresh air into the rooms. The air becomes very humid and stale, not good for sleeping. If they could fix this one problem it would be a great place to stay.

Pretty nice way how to show up feeling from be on a battleship even she's already more than 70 years sank.

So you've got main and secondary batteries on a ground in 1:1 scale and also rangefinder exact distance from a bow of the ship so you can imagine how was IJN Yamato was big.

It's actually pretty cool to watch from like middle of a ship towards the bow and use imagination how it was looked like.
PERFECT spot for pictures! Sunset & the night view are stunning. Fun to watch the ferries & SuperJet come & go.
it is very beautiful place for a walk and relax

"Yamato Wharf" is located on the sea side of Yamato Museum.
From here, you can see the JMU (Japan Marine United) dock, the Japan Maritime Self-Defense Force's submarines and escort ships, and the ships that come and go at the Kure Chuo Pier.

The plaza named ``Yamato'' is designed to resemble a full-sized battleship Yamato, and is a reproduction of the left half of the front deck of the battleship Yamato.
The battleship Yamato was said to have a total length of 263 meters and a width of 39 meters, and the left half of the foredeck of the battleship Yamato, which is half the length and half the width, is this size, so if you stand here, you can actually see it. I think you can get a real sense of how big the battleship Yamato was.
Also, if you look at it from the observation deck on the 5th floor of Kure Chuo Pier Terminal, which is right next to it, you can get a better idea of ​​its size.

There are places to eat nearby, so why not take some time to stop by when you come to the Yamato Museum or the Japan Maritime Self-Defense Force Kure Museum?

It is a place with quite beautiful scenery, and there are two submarines behind it. One of them is the Maritime Self-Defense Force Museum, which has free admission. There is a lot of information about submarines in the museum. There is a ferry terminal on the left side of the square, and there is a viewing group inside the ferry terminal. You can take a tour boat to visit the Maritime Self-Defense Force exhibition and submarines. The cost is 1,500 yen, and the whole tour takes about half an hour.

data.formatted_address: Japan, 〒739-0505 広島県廿日市市宮島町幸町
data.name: Machiya Street

reviews.text: THE retail street of miyajima catering to day visitors.  Opens mostly after 1030am and shuts down by 5pm.  Several grilled oysters places and many mimoji shops. Even a Starbucks (which is a horrifying sight)  Gets crowded when students come on field trips from the mainland.   While the streets are mostly narrow and old school small town feeling, the modern commerce is definitely coming in.   See my reviews of a couple shops on the street for detailed reviews
Walking street with foods on both sides

This street is located one block from the Omotesando shopping street, which can be called the main street of Miyajima, and it is clear that efforts are being made to preserve the scenery of the townscape.

It's much different from the crowded shopping streets, and there are fewer people so you can walk around more leisurely.
It runs parallel to the shopping street and the destination is almost the same, so if you are stuck with the crowds, I think it would be a good idea to take this street.

I saw lanterns with pictures of goldfish hanging up in each shop and house, and I thought it was a festival, but one of the shops told me that it was an initiative to liven up the street.

Each goldfish had a different pattern, so it was fun to look at each one.
A townscape with an atmosphere that makes you think you are in Kyoto for a moment 👌 A relaxing place

There are many souvenir shops, and as you enter the crowded Omotesando street, there are not many people, and the atmosphere is nice and calm.There are also several stylish cafes in old houses, making it a very pleasant street.

data.formatted_address: Hijiyama, 5 Hijiyamakoen, Minami Ward, Hiroshima, 732-0815, Japan
data.name: Hijiyama

reviews.text: If you enjoy the outdoors & beautiful views, do not miss this park. We spent 3 hours here. You can enjoy stunning 360 views of Hiroshima. Great spot for sunset.

reviews.author_name: わたしはだれでしょう
reviews.text:
2 kilometers from the center of the A-bomb explosion. This mountain blocked the blast and the back side of the mountain remained unharmed.
You can get a panoramic view of Hiroshima city from the observation deck in front of the Radiation Effects Research Foundation(RERF).  Hijiyama Park, located on top of the mountain, is home to the Museum of Contemporary Art (MOCA) and the Manga Library.
Visit by using Maple Loop's Orange Line or bicycle sharing (Peacecle).  Of course you can also walk. It takes about 25 minutes from Hiroshima Station to the museum.  If you have a 1-day streetcar pass, get off at the Hijiyama-shita tram stop and walk up for about 10 minutes.
Good place for a walk in the day, not at night as it is not well-lit. There is a museum of contemporary art  and a manga library. There are also cemeteries at some parts of this huge garden.
Scenic , underrated place..not many tourists but can be confusing

Great place for a walk or for taking in views of the city. Feels like you're in a great big forest in the middle of Hiroshima. The walk up can be tough, but near the Aeon Mall there is in escalator if you want to avoid the walk. There's plenty to do up here including an art museum, a manga library, a playground, and a nice open field area for throwing or kicking a few balls around. I love going up here and think everyone should check it out.
The natural scenery here is so beautiful, so quiet that you can see the entire city and the sea of ​​Hiroshima at the same time.

early morning trekking
Sunshine spreads over Hiroshima city

Be careful as the area near the top of the mountain is rocky and slippery.

You can reach it by walking about 5 minutes south from the top of Mt. Onaga.

The view from here is recommended as you can see the entire area.
A special place where you can see Hiroshima's mountains, sky, city, and sea all at once! ︎

reviews.author_name: やまぎわショートカット
reviews.text:
You can climb it from Yamane Daisan Park.
You can also traverse from Mt. Onagayama.
The mountain trail from Shokoji Temple is closed to traffic.
It has become.

data.name: Hiroshima City Mitaki Boys' Nature House

reviews.text: An absolutely fantastic nature playground that is completely free of charge. Our kids were 8 and 9 years of age and had a fantastic few hours running round the different courses. Make sure your kids wear shorts and outdoor shoes. The park is really shady so no need for hats or sunglasses. Might be worth stopping off at a 7-Eleven before arriving to get some provisions.
Children's challenge place. If you go there with children you have to look carefully which challenge better for child. Because if your child too little, may not overcome some challenges.

Its a great place for groups but be prepared because the food is japanese size... The food is not the best quality but at least you get unlimited rice. Its cheap to stay there so I recomend it. Enjoy!
A nice place for kids' camping. They can learn about following rules and help each others. It's about 15 min walking from Mitaki Station.

Although the equipment is a bit old, there is an athletics area that you can play for free✨ Please register at the entrance of the building 😌 Children of elementary school age can enjoy it 💕 If you climb a little above the area where the athletics area is, you can see a panoramic view of Hiroshima city and there is a very nice view. You can see it 🏙️ Please note that there are only about 10 parking spaces for athletic users 🚗

data.formatted_address: Dobutsuen Asacho, Asakita Ward, Hiroshima, 731-3355, Japan
data.name: Asa Zoo

reviews.text: If you have a baby they have a rental stroller for only 350yen. And wheel chairs for adults. .And please always have a alcohol in your pocket for sanitized. its a long walk at the same time u got exercise while enjoying. . we buy a ticket good for 1 year for only 1500yen. Anytime we can go there 😊😊😊 dont forget to wear facemask for safety❤️

Wonderful day spent wandering the gardens and visiting the animals. Overall cages were sized pretty well and the animals all looked happy and had friends to hang out with (except for the solitary animals like the cheetah).
An amazing zoo my partner and I found while in Hiroshima. It did take us an hour bus ride to get there though. Overall it was a fun half a day to explore.
I went on a rainy day. However, the animals were lively and enjoyed.

Had a great time with me wife n little girls. There may have been a few big hills but besides that they had an awesome amount of animals and a lot of places to sit rest or even picnic. They even had an area for the little ones to pet animals and also go on a slide. The staff was friendly and the park was very clean. Will be taking the kids back soon.
I was able to ride a go-kart for about 100 yen.There are many open spaces here, so I would like to bring the ball next time.
Late upload... one year ago .. it's a nice place

A great find. The place is designed to show kids about road rules as a pedestrian and a driver. It has a rather large playground and a few tables to have a picnic. Good for a few hours of fun. The cars are 100 yen for a single driver and 150 yen for doubles (kids under 8) and gets you a map of the course.

Awesome for kids. 3 rd graders ( approx) are cutoff age
-100 Yen a lap. Ticket machine is at entrance
-Not fast but fun for little ones.
-Parents can grab a ticket as well to drive with kids around track.
-Small City with stop lights. 400 square meters or so.
If you want your child teach traffic regulation. This is good place to go.

This is a popular shopping arcade. It is only about 5 mins walk from the Peace Memorial Park. The street is covered, wide and filled with many interesting shops. There are restaurants, karaoke bars, gaming arcades, clothing stores, anime shops, etc.
Covered street mall near the Peace park You can find a variety of shops like Daiso and Uniglo The famous Ichiran Ramen shop is also located in this mall
Great place to wander if you are trying to escape the rain. Many of the shops etc. don’t come to life until lunch time.

Just a short walk away from the Peace Museum, I discovered a bustling shopping district. This vibrant area is teeming with an array of shops offering a wide selection of items, ranging from shoes and bags to clothing and daily necessities. It's a shopper's paradise, catering to diverse tastes and needs.

Aside from shopping, the district also provides various entertainment options. You can indulge in some old-fashioned fun at the arcade or belt out your favorite tunes at a karaoke establishment. These additional attractions add an extra layer of enjoyment to your visit, ensuring there's something for everyone.

During my visit on a Monday evening for dinner, I was pleased to find that the district was not overly crowded. This created a relaxed and comfortable atmosphere, allowing me to explore the shops and enjoy my meal without feeling rushed or overwhelmed.

Whether you're looking for a shopping spree or a lively evening out, this shopping district has it all. Its proximity to the Peace Museum makes it a convenient stop for visitors, providing a delightful blend of retail therapy and entertainment options.
Nice shopping street near the bomb dome. Lots of food places. And shops. Unfortunately things close at 8pm.
Best place to by traditional snacks, honey, and other related Hiroshima food. one of the great places to test and buy Hiroshima’s traditional omiyage.

Hiroshima Local Products Plaza is a great place to discover products from Hiroshima and the surrounding nearby areas.

Here you can find local honey sourced from the Miyajima and other local bee farms as well as local alcoholic and non-alcoholic drinks, cooking ingredients, jams, snacks, spreads and more.

This Shopping Plaza has a very local vibe, but there is an information center at the back with a variety of travel guides, maps and information for international travelers as well.

Free samples of different seasonal items are at the front of the shop to entice people to come in and shop.

Have a look for the special seasonal items such as the ornate dolls on display for Girls day (in March) on display from the end of January.

There is very little English in terms of labeling, but the staff are eager to help and the atmosphere is very welcoming.

Unfortunately most products are in plastic packaging and single-use plastic bags are in use, but they are happy for you to use your own bag if you have one. There are also many products in glass or metal containers which can more easily be recycled or reused in Japan.
We were able to buy local souvenirs and local delicacies.
A local mart that sells specialties in Hiroshima. Come here to support small businesses.
Good place to buy regional speciality foods of Hiroshima and the surrounding area.

Statue of a Prayer for Peace

A child held by his mother is playing a trumpet, with a crescent moon in the foreground.

The meaning of creation “From parents to child, not yesterday but tomorrow, the crescent moon will become full moon. I want to sound the trumpet for peace in the search of the new future.”
This park and its museum made my 2 hour trip from Osaka worth while.
Wonderful park of a sad reminder. Thank you to the people that take such great care of this place.
Nice park
Very nice memorial
Visited this place during weekday, and somehow this park was stormed by a lot of students(maybe having a study tour?)
The Monument of prayer is a beautiful statue. The verse in Japanese opposite was penned by the local poet.
Although small this memorial is a beautiful symbol for the families.
God bless innocent people

Created by sculptor Kasumi Yokoe, it is a statue of a young couple holding a child standing on a pedestal.
To the right of the pedestal is a monument with a poem written by a Hiroshima-born poet titled ``Pray for Peace and Calm the Spirit.''

A small art gallery showcasing local artist works in oil, acrylic, glass and sculpture. I was surprised to see two works by Dali and one by Rembrandt. Level 2 is general gallery, Level 3 is for special exhibitions which costs more.

Get the combo ticket with Shukkeien Garden (which is a must see) and works out to amazing value. As I was the only one in the museum late afternoon I did feel like I was being watched like a hawk by the staff in each gallery room.

Pay attention to the signage which shows what you can take a photograph of and what is prohibited.
Highly recommend. Pay the extra to get the audio. It's worth it.

I hadn't planned to visit the museum but I got the combined ticket with Shukkeien Garden so had a look around. I was pleasantly surprised! It's a lovely, modern building full of art from local artists and some international artists (like the Dali below). I didn't pay extra for the special exhibit but there was still plenty to impress me, and the staff were very helpful with pointing out the art that I could take pictures of. The cafe on the top floor was very nice, with a lovely view of the garden, and the gift shop had a great selection of books and knick-knacks.

Hiroshima Prefectural Museum is a decent art museum. The museum is located next to the garden and has a few different areas showing paintings, decorative arts, etc. It’s a  in Hiroshima.

Please note that you can buy combo ticket for entering both the museum and Shukkeien Garden. If you use the combo ticket and want to enter the garden from the museum, please remember to keep the ticket as the door requires scanning the barcode on your ticket to unlock.

Brilliant and world class museum. Surprised to see the master piece of Dali and other global artists here, while appreciate other Japanese and Hiroshima prefecture artists with work about the tragedy here. The 8:15am by Ay-o was really striking to me, visually and the emotion it evoked as well as the details of a normal life were depicted in the artwork under the impact of the tragedy yet a rose still managed to bloom, representing love, hope and a new beginning, as least from my personal take. You will also find little corner with breathtaking view of the nature and view. Love the place to bits.

data.formatted_address: Japan, 〒739-0488 Hiroshima, Hatsukaichi, Ōno, 亀ケ岡１０７０１
data.name: Umi-Mori Art Museum

reviews.text: At first  I thought this hideous thing to be a mosque. Then I realized Japan would never let that happen, so I asked Google. It really does ruin an otherwise great view.

The most ugliest sight ruining the mountain. A complete desecration, violating the natural and sacred landscape. Very suprised this was allowed to happen. The fact that it's an art museum is even worse.... An art museum is supposed to value beauty right? So why did they think this was a good idea. It stands out like a sore thumb, so you can't take your eyes off it when you look out to gaze at the water or mountains. Absolutely dreadful this was allowed to happen. Tear it down.

It's a very nice museum. It is not too big and has small Exhibitions about Japanese culture and/or a specific world wide topic. It is on top of a small mountain, therefore, it is advised to ask the restaurant (which you should definitely visit) if they could give a ride up there. They are always happy to help out.
Besides, in the museum is a balcony area where you can enjoy a cup of tea. I'm sure if there wouldn't be Corona, they would offer more.. But the view is breathtaking taking and I would have liked to stay all day long.

Flew 8K miles from Texas to visit the beautiful Itsukushima shrine; it was cloudy, so I sat to meditate, then when clouds opened I saw a hideous, white & gold Dr Evil museum in the middle of a perfectly serene mountain. Japan, please paint it mountain green so that it becomes invisible!

A beautiful scenery: a shrine in the sea, a pagoda to the right, lots of nature, mountains.... But then you notice a strange white thing out of the corner of your eye. You look to the left, a humongous building that is really good at what it does, destroying the whole scenery. It looks like the incarnation of a villain in the form of a building, disrupting peaceful moments. It won't take you long to find it in the attachment.
Wonderful museum, different variety of art exhibitions every month or so, always enjoy my time there ♥️

Many interesting exhibitions were held here. I have visited here several times for various exhibitions. Even though the place is very small, it’s managed well. The staffs are very friendly and have an excellent service mind.

4/9~6/9, 2024
Admire the “John Paul II Museum Exhibition” (commemorating the 50th anniversary of the establishment of Higashihiroshima City)
Participate in a curator's gallery talk at a related event
Same-day ticket: 1,300 yen (general) 900 yen (university), free for high school students and younger
*20% discount on Saturdays for children under high school age (up to 2 people)

61 items from the well-known John Paul II Museum, a private collection in Warsaw, the capital of Poland, a neighboring country of Ukraine.

I thought it was a religious painting, but it deepens when I look at the portraits that focus on women and listen to a talk.
It's also great that you can re-enter after the talk ends and enjoy the show on your own.

Since I was using JR, it took less than 10 minutes to walk from Saijo Station along the wide, well-maintained sidewalk. very convenient.

I went to the ``John Paul II Museum Exhibition'' in Poland, which was held to commemorate the 50th anniversary of Higashihiroshima's incorporation.
There are 61 works on display depicting the Virgin and Child, Venus, angels, etc.
This museum opened in 2020, so it is a new museum.
It's about a 5-minute walk from Saijo Station and is across from Higashihiroshima City Hall.
The main entrance is flat and there is a ramp at the south exit, so it is wheelchair accessible.

I had a hard time finding a place to park my bike in the middle of the city.😢There was a spacious park in front of the park, and I saw people taking a leisurely stroll and families with their children. Although the museum was exhibiting its collection, I was able to encounter wonderful works such as ceramics and prints. Due to time constraints, I was only able to watch it for an hour, but I wish I had watched it more thoroughly. 😆👍

This museum is located about 5 minutes by car from Yoshiwa Interchange.
I think many people are familiar with Qvere Yoshikazu.

With one admission ticket, you can see two types of exhibits: the exhibits that are updated every three months and the permanent exhibits.
(This time it was a work by sculptor Taki Tamada)

Wheelchair and stroller rental available
There are also exhibits in the new building next door (you can continue to enter with an admission ticket to the Woodwan Museum of Art)

Because it is a complex facility, you can enjoy skiing, hot spring facilities, eating and drinking, and nature.

[2024.7]
Great private museum! As expected from a building materials manufacturer, plenty of wood is used, and the facility itself is wonderful! The collection of paintings is also worth seeing.

I've been curious about it since the days when it was renamed the Juken Art Museum, and finally decided to visit it. I arrived at the Yoshiwa Interchange while admiring the autumn leaves on the Chugoku Expressway. I arrived at the Woodwan Museum of Art, overlooking rice paddies and fields, and was greeted by its small and cute appearance. This special exhibition mainly features Ejoe's drawings of the faces of Eastern and Western painters using flowing brushstrokes, and the deformed works of Van Gogh, Renoir, and Tsuguharu Fujita that are housed in the museum were particularly eye-catching. . Personally, something worth mentioning is Ryusei Kishida's "Reiko statue", which I have not liked for some time because I thought it was "creepy". However, I was impressed by the radiant skin of the real thing, the dreamy eyes despite the single layer, and the precise reproduction of the crocheted shawl, making it a masterpiece. In addition to paintings, it was a museum that made you feel rich, with glass crafts from Galle, porcelain from Meissen, and Satsuma ware with luxurious gold brocade.

I asked for a drive.
I'm impressed by the volume
Of course there are famous paintings, but the most impressive thing is the glass and ceramics in the annex.
A wonderful collection of Galle, Dome, Satsuma ware, Meissen, Baccarat, etc.
The adjacent facilities offer lodging, meals, hot springs, golf, skiing, and more for all seasons.

It's a comfortable place.
The pictures displayed were also wonderful.
pictures and flowers
There are so many delicate paintings that you could mistake them for photographs.
I also learned about the meaning of flowers.
thank you.

data.name: アートギャラリーミヤウチ

reviews.text: Great little art gallery that has unique, family friendly events. The current/latest as of this writing is a masking tape art exhibit and workspace.
It's spacious and beautiful. The walls are white, so it feels very bright, and you can take your time exploring the exhibits (^^)
There were various works and I enjoyed them.
I'm doing some pretty interesting projects. The staff are also polite and likable. Recommended.
It was small but nice. Parking is available at the back entrance.

Gorgeous art museum with nice exhibition (glasses: 5 July 2023) and beautiful architecture.

Also the garden was amazing even though I went there on the rainy day, it still impressive!

Last one, I really like the colorful of each boxes. It made my day.

Wonderful place to spend an afternoon. Bit difficult to find as you have to drive all the way around the park in order to get into it but well worth the hunt. The museum itself is almost a piece of art between the colorful mobile boxes and the mirrored surfaces of the exterior.

Found this place completely by accident while driving through the nearby public park. Beautiful new and modern with great landscaping. Apparently it is part resort and you will be able stay in villas.
The architecture for the museum is amazing

We visited the Shimose Museum of Art, which was selected as one of the 7 most beautiful museums in the world by the International Versailles Prize Organization in 2024. At the same time, an exhibition of Japanese painting master Matazo Kayama was also held, which was a good deal.
I thought it was a wonderful building, as it has been praised all over the world. The surrounding area is also a park, so even families can enjoy it.
A particularly unique impression is the mobile exhibition booth. Apparently it floats on the water and can change its layout.
The garden named after Emile Gallé was also beautifully landscaped and wonderful. This is a recommended spot.

data.formatted_address: 1-chōme-9-９番地先 Ōtemachi, Naka Ward, Hiroshima, 730-0051, Japan
data.name: Hiroshima World Heritage River Cruise

reviews.text:
A fine, sometimes bumpy ride to Miyajima.
It’s a bit high in price, but if you stay near the Atomic Dome, and have the extra cash I would do it, just to not have to ride the train to the ferry.

It’s a 45min trip, and it is possible to stand on the deck as long as the boat is not on the open sea.

Remember to exchange you Round trip ticket to a boarding pass when you get to the Island.

If you're visiting Hiroshima, taking the world heritage cruise to Miyajima is an essential and convenient mode of transportation. The journey is a pleasant 45-minute boat ride, allowing you to bypass the need for trains and the JR ferry, saving you valuable time.

As of January 2024, the cost for a round trip was 4,000 yen for adults, with children's tickets available at half price.

The only drawback I encountered with this cruise is the timing of the last return trip at 5:30 PM, which I found to be too early. This limited the amount of time I could spend enjoying my day trip on the island.

We took the river cruise to Miyajima island from near the atomic dome.

To save you from going via bus and train this is a more convenient option. It does cost more but you probably save time to get there, it’s 45 mins and a single route.

There are set times, worth going early and coming back on the last ferry at 5:30pm. This should give you enough time to explore the island.

Remember to exchange the round trip ticket to a boarding pass when you get to the Island.

Loved this cruise to get from Peace Memorial Park to Miyajima. Super convenient for those who are doing the standard sightseeing spots in the area. It was easy to buy a round trip ticket, and the ride itself was relaxing. They had a video screen teaching the history of all the bridges we passed under and the nearby landmarks as well, which was much appreciated. I’d recommend this to anyone traveling between the two areas.

40~min boat ride to Miyajima. Very expensive though practical if you want to avoid the train(s) + ferry from Hiroshima. They accept big luggage. Close to no view if you're not sitting next to the windows (50/50).

My girlfriend and I popped in to see a Kagura performance, which was a very special treat. If you’re in Hiroshima on a Wednesday evening, you can line up an hour before the show starts for unreserved tickets (our seats were perfect despite being unreserved!). Subtitle screens are also located on either side of the stage for English speakers. It was great fun watching the dancers perform mesmerizing movements to bring an eight-headed folktale dragon to life, and the live music was amazing! Maybe I wish it was scarier?

An important museum for anyone who cares about peace.
It is especially important to listen to the testimony of the survivors of the bombing, we heard from the daughter of a survivor and it added a lot of knowledge about the city before and after the bombing.
I went to the Wednesday night Kagura. This was my first japanese theatre experience and it did not dissapoint. There were also english discriptions of what was going on on tv screens which was nice

We had a great time watching two Kagura performances at this cultural centre. They take place on Wednesday evenings across the summer. The shows were dramatic, the dancing entertaining and the costumes incredibly colourful and elaborate.
Tickets are on sale for 1,000 yen at the venue from 5pm and doors open at 6pm. The first show doesn't start until 7pm but as the seats are unreserved lots of people do go in at 6pm to ensure a good view / camera angle. The shows both last about 45 minutes with a 15 minute break between the end of the first show and the second starting at 8pm. You can also stay after the second show to take a closer look at the costumes and for further photo opportunities.
Overall these were fantastic (extremely photogenic) performances from a semi-professional community theatre group.
Kagura show was great. 100% recommend it

We came here spring season
So beautiful place its a kids friendly too
So nice to stay for nature lovers
There's a rental electric bike for adults for 2 hours its only 500yen
This is a big place so get ready for a long happy walk while viewing a different types of plats❤️ we enjoy this place so much😍

Great garden. Many different kind of plants. From beautiful flowers, to huge cacti and to carnivorous plants. It has a big pond where you can feed fish for ¥100.

I'm not a big flower/garden fan but this garden was a pleasure to visit on my trip

This is a great botanical garden located in hiroshima.  Huge greenhouse and smaller greenhouses with tropical plants, fruiting plants, cacti, and water plants.  Amazing collection especially given the large size of some of the plants (baobab and bananas are impressive) Outside there are many native and local plants and plants from around the world.  We came in winter and it was amazing how many plants were in bloom and the beautiful flowers on display.

Lots of toilets and easy parking.  Lots of paths to walk and also a few playplaces for kids.  There is a small shop that includes plants for sale and other small items.  Highly recommend if you like exotic plants and want to spend a few hours walking around.

It’s a nice place to visit
In summer it would good for kids since it has a place where they can play with water…
There are a variety of flowers…
Every 30 minutes they generate some mist over the greens… really nice to see and very cool in a hot summer day
Very well organized, peaceful, inspiring botanical garden with a variety of plants and landscapes. Best enjoyed by visitors who aren’t scared of walking uphills.

Wow, what a beautiful trail that was touted as a light sloping trail. However, there are a significant amount of varying steps. Highly recommend. Pro tip: If you are going to hike this trail you need to leave adequate time 3+ hours and be sure that you are going to make it back before dark as there is no lighting. Also, keep in mind that you are going to need to catch the ferry back as well. Pro tip 2: The cable cars stop taking passengers up at 4 PM so that you can walk back down before 7 PM when it is dark. Pro tip 3: the deer on the island are magical and easy to pet and live on. Move slowly and they will let you pet them.
It's quite tough up, but it's really worth it. Especially when the ropeway is not running, as it was our case. Take enough water and a snack!

Momijidani Course is a popular hiking path that connects Momijidani Park and Mount Misen1. It’s approximately 2 kilometers long and took me around 1 hour to walk from Mount Misen Observatory to the park. The path is well-trodden and you will occasionally see other hikers along the way. The path is mainly formed by dirt and stone stairs. Visitors can enjoy the natural environment when walking along this path.

If you have time and would like to enjoy the natural part of Miyajima Island, Momijidani Course is a good option.

We’re pretty fast hikers and made it up in 45 minutes and down in 35. It’s not terribly difficult, just wear good shoes. When you get to the top fork, make a right for the best view (don’t go towards the ropeway). Really spectacular observatory!
Very nice Mountain, with a good view

data.formatted_address: 3 Chome-18 Koiosako, Nishi Ward, Hiroshima, 733-0804, Japan
data.name: 高峠山 展望岩🌿

reviews.text: It's easily accessible from Ryuo Park and Koi Osako Danchi, and it's a popular spot with bamboo benches that overlooks Hiroshima city center. It is also a train viewing spot where you can see the Shinkansen running through the city of Hiroshima.

Hiking in the mountains ⛰️I learned about it after a person who loves mountaineering told me that it was a recommended course for them.

It took about 30 minutes to climb Stacola from Mitaki-dera Temple to the ridge of Sokayama, and from there it took about 15 minutes to branch off to the left and follow the gentle traverse.
The view is very nice ♪ The city center ☆ The Funairi area is so close that you can see Hiroshima Bay to Mt. Shimoyama and other mountains in the Kure area.
One way to go down is on the Osako Danchi side of Ryuo Park Road (slope stairs).
The other one goes around the nature house, but I don't know the correct course yet, but I'd like to walk with the person who taught me about it someday🕊️

The mountain is easy to climb, there are many people in the city, and the sidewalks are maintained comfortably with the support of enthusiasts, making it easy to walk.
Among these, this one is highly recommended, as it is easily accessible from JR Mitaki Station and Bus Mitaki Line, and is a satoyama village, but it takes you through the varied ``Mtakiyama A Course,'' which includes the approach to the temple, temple precincts, waterfalls, and a mountain stream and bamboo forest behind the temple.
Thank you for the green 🌿

In mid-April 2022, the warm days continued, and when the Yoshino cherry trees had finished blooming in the city, wild cherry blossoms colored the mountainside in the Mitaki Mountains, and red-purple azaleas were already in full bloom along the mountain trail. ♪
I feel grateful for the peaceful four seasons of Japan.

*The rule to pass through Mitaki-dera Temple is to pay the 200 yen admission fee at the entrance. Insert coins and enjoy the sounds♪
You can climb the Mitaki Children's Nature House from the Koi-gami direction, and you can see the western side of Hiroshima City. It was hanging from a branch. It has now been removed.

A familiar observation deck in Hiroshima city. It is a wonderful location of 235m where you can see the entire Hiroshima city area - Kure/Ondo Seto - Yamaguchi Prefecture/Suo Oshima - Iwakuni - Hiroshima City's westernmost point, Mt. Omine. When the Hiroshima Port Fireworks Festival is held, the atmosphere is like watching the fireworks from a helicopter. The closest starting point is the stairs leading to the summit from Osako Danchi 3-35 (no parking lot). If you are driving, please park at the Ryuo Park parking lot and walk.
It's a mountain 🗻 that you can easily climb.

So glad we decided to do this trial rather than the one that starts at the temple. We only saw 1 other person whilst hiking up! It took about 1.5 hours to reach the top with frequent water stops, it is a challenging hike with many steps but it’s so worth it to be surrounded in a peaceful ancient forest (it feels like you’re in a ghibli movie) on the way down we decided to take the popular route and wow it was very busy we must of seen about 50 people pass at least!

Amazing forests and a breathtaking scene from the top, but prepare for about 1000 stone steps. Get ready to walk this over 500m mountain directly from sea level! This took us about 1.5-2 hours as average hikers. If you’re tired after you can take the rope way down, but the last car is at 4:30pm!

If you want an easier hike, take the rope way to the top from the other side and walk down this route. Going up is a serious workout for your calves and knees.

This is not a 24 hour path. Do not take it after dark.

Terrifying but beautiful at the same time. We went up via the ropeway, so only actually walked half this route while descending the mountain; definitely not something one should do when pouring rain. Thankfully, it only sprinkled a little on us.
The path is very very steep and made up of a lot of rock steps. I can't even begin to imagine the amount of hours that went into forming the route.
Wish there were a few more sign posts that stated how much farther one had left to go, and really wouldn't have minded just a couple guard rails here and there....

If you like hikking, animals and nature this is the place to be!

Very enjoyable path with lots of hidden gems to discover along the way with statues, little shrinees, wild animals (they are not afraid of humans) and of course fresh air and nature
Great peaceful and quiet walk. In fall it's wonderful with red leaves and wild deers.

data.formatted_address: 1 Chome Ushitayama, Higashi Ward, Hiroshima, 732-0014, Japan
data.name: 牛田山

reviews.text: Amazing! Don't miss this spot
Although it is a low mountain at 261m, there are trailheads in various places so you can enjoy it. It's perfect if you have some free time and want to climb a little.

◯Ushidayama (altitude 260.7m) Geographical Survey Institute of Japan

Was it built by a local person at the top of the mountain?
It's a small hut with a desk and chairs inside.
You can take a break

View from the mountaintop
The cityscape of Hiroshima city beyond Futabayama (Stupa)
Beyond that, Miyajima (Itsukushima) in Aki, etc.
You can see the islands of the Seto Inland Sea.

I climbed from the Tosaka Kurumeki trailhead.

(Hiroshima)
2023.01.10

◯Night view (twilight) photography

(Hiroshima)
2023.05.02

No matter what time you come, it's a refreshing place 🎵 Around 50 people visit every day. Mr. Haraguchi, who is recommended by points, will be waiting for you for over an hour! ️
Thank you 🙆

It takes 10 minutes from the north exit of Hiroshima Station to Toshogu Shrine, where the trailhead is located. There is a trailhead behind the shrine. It takes about 20 minutes to reach Mt. Futaba while climbing the stairs where the Inari statue is enshrined. After enjoying the view of Hiroshima city, we head down to the residential area and head back toward Mt. Onaga from behind the apartment building. After breaking a sweat from the steep climb, we reached the top in 15 minutes. Although it is hidden by trees, the view to the southwest is open. From Mt. Onaga, follow the ridgeline toward Mt. Ushida. You'll meet many hikers and trail runners along the way, and there are signs at each intersection, so you won't get lost. Ushidayama has benches and places to take shelter from the rain. On the way down, head for Ushida Station via Kandayama. This is an easy and very good course for a weekend hike near Hiroshima city.

I climbed the western route from behind Bishamondo Tahoto Pagoda. Although it is steep, the stairs are well maintained. It's quite a steep slope, so I recommend using poles with both hands. You can't see the view from the top because of the trees, but you can get a great view from the bench located a little further down from the top. There was a rest area above the parking lot at the top.
I climbed up from Bishamon and arrived here. I came here by car many times when I was young! nostalgic. From here, we will aim for the summit of Mt. Abu.

・There are several parking lots. I mean, it feels like a rather wide road.
・There is a toilet (not clean, not even water, and it doesn't even have the shape of a toilet)
・Walk a little. It's not spicy at all
・Not the one with the building. The opposite.
・Once you reach the wooden signs that say East-bound promenade and West-bound promenade, go a little further.
・I went from the west promenade. Even if I say I've been there, I'll be there soon. I'm going down the mountain for a bit, so I'm worried about whether the scenery will expand from here on out, but it does.
・At night, wild deer were wandering around.
・You can see the night view of Hiroshima. so beautiful.

[Added on August 17, 2022]
・I went there during the day.
・Good during the day too.
・But night is probably the best time.

The result is the best

The view is great if you visit on a clear day. You can reach the top by car, but the road is narrow and those who are not confident in driving may not want to do so. There are also chairs and tables, making it a nice place to eat.

I rode my bicycle up the forest road next to the Midorii water treatment plant. The top of the mountain was cluttered with TV towers and other objects, and the view was only so-so, but the view of Hiroshima city from the ``Western promenade'' a little further down from the top was the most amazing.
We recommend driving your car or bicycle along the forest road, parking at the parking lot at the Bishamondo entrance, and then going around the mountain by climbing in the east direction, descending in the west direction, and visiting Bishamondo Temple.

Hiking up Mt. Takeda 411m. I was able to park at the Ikoinomori parking lot (approx. 10 cars), but if you can't park, you'll have no choice but to go down to the residential area below, so be very careful.
As of November 23, 2020, the mountain itself is covered in deep autumn leaves, and the trail is hard to get lost after an hour of climbing and 40 minutes of descent. There are some rocky spots along the way, but the risk is generally low. The view is great even without gas. I didn't expect to be able to see as far as Ninoshima. It's a good idea to bring along for hiking and building physical fitness, but it's better to be prepared with proper clothes, luggage, and shoes.

・Parking available (several spaces)
・I forgot about the toilet. Maybe there was.
・Entrance to Mt. Takeda mountain climbing. There are probably several routes to Mt. Takeda, and this is just one of them.

The result is the best
Free parking nearby.

There is a paved parking lot in front of the mountain trail and a parking space nearby (can park about 15 cars).
There are restrooms, but it's a mountain park, so bring your own paper. There is no running water or vending machines, so be sure to prepare water for washing your hands and drinking water in advance.
The mountain trail itself is well-maintained and has easy-to-understand information boards, so it's a good place to enjoy trekking with light clothing, but be careful as some parts of the trail can become slippery during or immediately after rain.
If you're going to walk all the way to Mitaki-dera Temple, it's a good idea to wear gloves (work gloves).
You can die by sprinting from below! Recommended for those who want to train!
